sources.snippet: The Cu Chi Tunnels were used by the Vietcong guerrillas during the Tet Offensive in 1968 and they’re a stark and frightening piece of the past. Why it’s so awesome: The Cu Chi Tunnels are a series of underground tunnels and chambers which stretch for 30km outside of the city and they were used by the Vietcong guerrillas during the Vietnam War. You can actually crawl through these tunnels now and experience what it must have been like during that time which is an extreme and viscerally important experience.
sources.shortName: 14 BEST Places to Visit in Ho Chi Minh (2024 Guide)

sources.snippet: If you love waterfalls, Giang Dien Waterfall is the right place for you to visit on a day trip from Saigon. Giang Dien Waterfall in Dong Nai province is now considered as the new eco-tourism area and attracts a lot of tourists from Ho Chi Minh City and neighboring provinces. Giang Dien Waterfall may not be as spectacular as the falls in the Central Highlands, but you will still feel really impressed by the beautiful scenery with lots of wild flowers and butterflies, and lust green trees.
sources.shortName: Best Places for Day Trip from Ho Chi Minh City

sources.snippet: Besides being the hustle and bustle of an economic hub, Ho Chi Minh City embraces historical vestiges appealing to both domestic and international tourists. The Cu Chi Tunnels are a wonder of Vietnam's unique military art, showing the resilient and indomitable will of the people of the "land of steel," one of the symbols of revolutionary heroism. Cu Chi Tunnels are situated in Cu Chi district - the outskirts northwest of Ho Chi Minh city, 70 kilometers away from the city center.
sources.siteName: Tourist Attractions in Ho Chi Minh | Vietnam Escape Tours
sources.shortName: Tourist Attractions in Ho Chi Minh

sources.snippet: Cu Chi Tunnels: Cu Chi Tunnels System is an underground defensive system in Cu Chi District, 70 km north-west from Ho Chi Minh City center. This tunnels system was excavated by the Viet Minh and the National Front for the Liberation of South Vietnam during the Indochina War (French War) in 1948 and the Vietnam War (American War to Vietnamese). The tunnels system includes an infirmary, several rooms, a kitchen, a storage room, an office, an underground tunnel system.
sources.shortName: Best Spots to See in Ho Chi Minh

sources.snippet: Despite its historic and cultural significance, Ho Chi Minh City is also one of the most dynamic spots in Vietnam, and you can see this through the cutting edge buildings and the exciting nightlife on offer here. If you want to sample some of the local delights, then the street food scene in the city is also one of the best in the country, and you can happily spend your days eating your way around Ho Chi Minh City, or join a dedicated food tour.
sources.shortName: 25 Best Things To Do In Ho Chi Minh City (Vietnam)

sources.snippet: Highlights: Like an underground village, the Cu Chi Tunnels are one of the three major relics in Ho Chi Minh City. The Cu Chi Tunnels played a surprisingly successful role in the various wars that Vietnam has experienced, so it has become a legendary and popular attraction. The Cu Chi Tunnel is 250 kilometers long and is composed of numerous tunnels less than 80 cm wide, which are divided into three layers, and the third layer is 8 meters deep.
sources.shortName: Top 18 Best Things to Do in Ho Chi Minh City

sources.snippet: The Cu Chi Tunnels are an extensive network of underground tunnels located in the Cu Chi district of Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam. They played a crucial role during the Vietnam War as a strategic base for the Viet Cong, providing shelter, supply routes, and hiding spots. Visitors can learn about the various traps and defensive mechanisms employed by the Viet Cong, as well as view examples of the weapons and equipment used during that time.
sources.shortName: 15 Unmissable Places to Visit in Ho Chi Minh City

sources.snippet: When talking about Ho Chi Minh City, people frequently think of it as Vietnam’s most contemporary and dynamic city, yet it’s also bearing its own historical marks. Not too far from Ho Chi Minh City centre which is only 57km away, there is a fascinating underground network called Cu Chi Tunnels. These tunnels spanned over 220km and played an important role in Vietnam”s extensive struggle for freedom during the Vietnam War.
sources.shortName: BEST PLACES TO VISIT NEAR HO CHI MINH CITY AIRPORT

sources.snippet: Tunnel your way back in time during your visit to the Cu Chi Tunnels. Located on the northwestern fringes of greater Ho Chi Minh City, the Cu Chi District is home to a network of over 250 kilometers used by the Viet Cong to evade American and South Vietnamese forces during the Vietnam War. Enter the tunnels at either one of two entrances, Ben Dinh, which is 35 kilometers away, and Ben Duoc, which is 70 kilometers away.
sources.shortName: 7 must-see attractions in HCMC

sources.snippet: About 60 kilometers from Ho Chi Minh City, the Cu Chi Tunnels are a must-see half-day trip and one of the top tours for visitors to the city. This vast 250-kilometer-plus network of tunnels served as the base for the Viet Cong's military operations during the Vietnam War. Soldiers used the excruciatingly cramped tunnels as hiding places, hospitals, communication bases, supply routes, and even living quarters.
sources.shortName: 13 Top-Rated Tourist Attractions in Ho Chi Minh City

sources.snippet: Situated about 70 km northwest of the city, the Cu Chi Tunnels are a vast underground network that Viet Cong soldiers used during the Vietnam War. Here, you can crawl through some of the safer, yet very tiny tunnels, learn about the ingenious traps set for enemies, and get a sense of life during wartime. The Cu Chi Tunnels are definitely the most popular day trip from Ho Chi Minh City.
sources.siteName: The Planet D: Adventure Travel Blog

sources.snippet: Stretching for over 220 km, Cu Chi Tunnels were an important Viet Cong base during the Vietnam War. When you are coming here, you will have a chance to discover an underground town, explore the fighting bunkers, dangerous booby traps, try shooting an AK47, M16 or machine guns and enjoy local special food such as steamed tapioca and hot tea which was the main food during the war.

placeMetadata.description: Sprawling underground tunnel complex used by Viet Cong soldiers, plus exhibits & war memorials.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Cu Chi Tunnels, a vast underground network utilized by Viet Cong soldiers during the war, offers visitors a chance to explore exhibits and war memorials. Tourists can also experience crawling through widened tunnels to gain insight into the soldiers' wartime struggles. Many find it hard to fathom how Vietnamese soldiers lived and fought in such conditions. Chinese-speaking guides provide vivid explanations of the historical significance, making it an educational experience for those unfamiliar with Vietnamese history.
placeMetadata.address: Phú Hiệp, Củ Chi, Hồ Chí Minh, Vietnam

reviews.reviewText:
Visiting the Cu Chi Tunnels was an incredible and eye-opening experience, offering deep insights into Vietnam’s history and the resilience of its people. We had booked a tour group, and the bus picked us up from the Old Quarter, making the journey convenient. The ride itself was smooth, and after reaching the site, our guide walked us through the history of the tunnels, explaining how the Vietnamese soldiers dug them by hand using basic tools, enduring immense hardships. These tunnels played a crucial role in their victory during the Vietnam War, allowing them to outmaneuver and resist much stronger forces.

There are two tunnels that visitors can enter, and going inside was both thrilling and humbling. At times, you have to crawl through extremely narrow spaces, truly experiencing the conditions the Vietnamese soldiers endured. The guide led us through the tunnels, ensuring safety while sharing fascinating details about their strategy, survival techniques, and daily life underground.

It was a great and lasting experience, making history come alive in a way that books never could. Highly recommend this tour to anyone visiting Vietnam! After the tour, we were conveniently dropped back at the District 1, wrapping up an unforgettable day.

I recently visited the Cu Chi Tunnels and it was such an eye-opening and unforgettable experience. Learning about the Vietnam War on-site made everything feel so real and emotional. I was truly amazed by the creativity and resilience of the Vietnamese people—how they were able to live, move, and survive underground in such extreme conditions is just incredible. It’s a powerful reminder of how thinking outside the box can make the impossible possible.

You actually get to experience the tunnels yourself, and let me tell you—it’s intense! The temperature was around 22°C, which helped, but you still have to bend, squat, crawl, and slide your way through tight, narrow passages. It’s physically exhausting, but also really fun and totally worth it.

One of the highlights for me was the shooting range. You can try out some of the actual types of guns used during the war. I got to fire one, and it was both thrilling and surreal—like stepping straight into history.

If you're visiting Vietnam and want a deeper understanding of its history, this place is a must-see. Just wear comfy clothes and prepare for a unique, hands-on adventure!

placeMetadata.name: War Remnants Museum

sources.snippet: To understand the US invasion of Vietnam, and contextualize its devastating impact on the country's civilians, this remarkable and deeply moving museum is…
sources.shortName: attractions Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City Region

sources.snippet: To understand where the Vietnamese people are coming from, we first have to learn about the history of the country, and there is no better place to learn about the atrocities committed during the Vietnam War than at the War Remnants Museum in Ho Chi Minh City. The museum consisted of 2 floors and a courtyard filled with old relics of war, such as American tanks and choppers, that were abandoned after the US military left the country haphazardly at the end of the Vietnam War. Inside, you will find a single room on the second floor dedicated to the Vietnamese version of the war, its motives, and how it unfolded from the perspective of the locals.
sources.shortName: 10 BEST Places to Visit in Ho Chi Minh City

sources.snippet: One of the most famous museums in Vietnam is the War Remnants Museum, first opened to the public in 1975. The museum primarily focuses on the Vietnam War, however, some exhibits relate to the first Indochina War with French colonialists. It is a reminder of the long and brutal Vietnam War, with many graphic photographs and American military equipment on display, which are the weapons were used by American troops against the Vietnamese at some point during the infamous war that lasted from 1945 until 1975.
sources.shortName: Top 7 attractions in Ho Chi Minh City

sources.snippet: When you’re visiting Ho Chi Minh, it’s important that you learn about this part of its history from the local point of view. Why it’s so awesome: Most people in western countries knows about the Vietnam War, but as you backpack around Vietnam you’ll think about it from new perspectives you may have never considered. In Ho Chi Minh, this war is often known as the American War, and this museum explores it through this very different viewpoint.
sources.shortName: 14 BEST Places to Visit in Ho Chi Minh (2024 Guide)

sources.snippet: The War Remnants Museum is one of the most popular museums in Vietnam, with harrowing exhibits related to the horrors of war in this battle-worn nation. The museum primarily focuses on the Vietnam War, however, some exhibits relate to the first Indochina War with French colonialists. It's a good idea to start on the top floor and work your way down, so you cap off your experience with the lighter exhibits on the ground floor.
sources.shortName: 13 Top-Rated Tourist Attractions in Ho Chi Minh City

sources.snippet: Located in District 3, the War Remnants Museum is a must-go place to learn Vietnamese history. It has heartbreaking exhibitions related to Vietnam War involving the French and American colonialists. The museum was opened in 1975 as “The House for Displaying War Crimes of American Imperialism and the Puppet Government,” but then got its name changed in 1993 after going under changes and renovations.
sources.shortName: 10+ Best Places To Visit In Ho Chi Minh Vietnam

sources.snippet: This museum offers Westerners a different view of the Vietnam War than they are probably used to hearing and seeing. The War Remnants Museum, which opened around 1975, was originally called the Exhibition House for U.S. and Puppet Crimes. That name was changed to the Exhibition House for Crimes of War and Aggression in 1990 before finally being changed to its current moniker in 1995.
sources.shortName: 10 Top Attractions in Ho Chi Minh City (+Map)

sources.snippet: The War Remnants Museum is a three-story museum holding countless artefacts and graphic photographs, including photographer Nick Ut’s Pulitzer Prize-winning shot, “The Terror of War.” Out-of-commission planes, tanks, bombs and helicopters decorate the courtyard. It is a sombre experience but one that leaves a lasting impression. Admission: 15,000 VNDHours of Operation: 7:30 a.m.

placeMetadata.description: Memorial museum exhibiting photographs, weapons & other objects from the Vietnam & Indochina wars.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: The War Remnants Museum stands as a poignant testament to the Vietnam and Indochina wars, showcasing an array of photographs, weapons, and artifacts that narrate the harrowing tales of conflict. Situated in Ho Chi Minh City, this museum is dedicated to preserving history while educating visitors about the impacts of war on Vietnam. It serves not only as a repository for historical evidence but also aims to instill a sense of peace and solidarity among nations.
placeMetadata.address: Phường 6, Quận 3, Hồ Chí Minh 700000, Vietnam

reviews.reviewText: Well worth a visit. This was a big event in the history of the country. And if you think it only finished 50 years ago! I’ve grown up only knowing one side of the story, but as usual there are two sides. There’s an interesting article about an American senator that served in Vietnam. Ive added some photos for interest. There’s a large indoors exhibition. The tiger cages were not what I was expecting.

We happened to visit the War Remnants museum on the 50th anniversary of reunification. So it was a huge day in Vietnam marking 50 years since the end of the war. The museum was only 80,000 Dong each (~£2.30) to get in. We felt this was amazing value.
Before entering me and my girlfriend had no knowledge about the Vietnam war. However exiting 3 hours later we felt as thought we knew a lot. Inside the museum you can read the full timeline of the war. It’s quite distressing seeing what the Americans did and many people were quite emotional. There are photos which are very disturbing and show the extent of the pain the Vietnamese went through.
Outside the building there were military vehicles and weapons which were fascinating to look at.
Overall really glad we went and it has given us a real insight to the horrors that occurred.
This really is a must if you are visiting Ho Chi Minh City.

The entrance is only 40K pp and it’s totally worth it. I imagine that the best way to do explore it would be from the third/second floor and going down, once the higher floor is about the earlier history of the country and the middle floor is much more dense about the war crimes. In my opinion this place is a must visit if you ever come to HCMC because it tells in so many details about the war and its history. Besides that, for all the westerns it’s an opportunity to get some knowledge besides that spread and teach in schools. I must say it’s a very dense visiting. I spent about 3h and wasn’t able to read everything

Typically when I visit a museum in America I'm both enlightened and uplifted - not the later case here in Vietnam😑. Horror. Dread. Empathy. Remorse? The images are too graphic to post. But if you've ever fought in war, heard stories from family members who have, or have been associated in any way with the destruction that wars cause, then well... you get the picture. As an American it's unsettling but at the same time unifying to share the experience with people from all different countries (and perspectives), including Vietnamese. If you're not emotionally moved after visiting then I can't imagine you're human.

A powerful and well-curated glimpse into Vietnam's history. The preserved war remnants tell compelling stories—both haunting and inspiring. A must-visit for anyone wanting to reflect on the past and appreciate the sacrifices that shaped the present.

The best place to visit in Saigon. You'll see how Vietnam and the US fought the war. Every minute detail of the war is being shown in the museum. I think it's such a great place to visit if you're interested in the history of Vietnam or you love reading about the world politics or international relations.

Lots of very interesting artefacts and exhibitions. Definitely worth visiting, however it does get pretty crowded. Found it hard to really absorb all the information due to the chaos of people around. Certainly not your typical "museum" atmosphere, but would still highly recommend.
There was a huge line for tickets stretching around the block, however I went with part of a private city tour and skipped the line entirely. Highly recommended doing it that way over just rocking up on a whim. As mentioned above, it was difficult to actually stand and read all the info, so having a private guide was certainly worth it!

If you want to learn about this tragic war, this is the spot! Very nice museum in the center of downtown. Outdoor and indoor exhibits with a decent shop for gifts. I was there with friends who are locals, have to admit some parts were very emotional. Makes you appreciate the fact I have never had to experience such a war in my lifetime.

placeMetadata.name: Ben Thanh Market

sources.snippet: Like I mentioned at the top of this list of top attractions in Ho Chi Minh City, I really liked Binh Tay Market, but there was no way I was going to leave out Ben Thanh Market either. Even as touristy as it may be, it’s a buzzing market, full of history, shopping stalls galore, and being located in the heart of Ho Chi Minh City’s District 1, it’s probably the most important central landmark of the city. You’ll find just about everything ever created or produced in Vietnam somewhere within the market lanes of Ben Thanh.
sources.shortName: 23 Things To Do In Saigon (Ho Chi Minh City): Top Attractions!

sources.snippet: Situated in downtown Ho Chi Minh City, bustling Ben Thanh Market is one of the attractions in Ho Chi Minh City which you must to visit once while you are in the city. It is located in District 1 is a great place to buy local handicrafts, branded goods, Vietnamese art and other souvenirs. Visiting this market, tourists can find eating stalls inside the market where you can get a taste of hawker-style Vietnamese cuisine or simply cool off with a cold drink when the bargaining becomes too much.
sources.shortName: Top 7 attractions in Ho Chi Minh City

sources.snippet: Highlights: This market is the largest trading market in Ho Chi Minh City, selling everything from food, daily necessities, and handicrafts. There are all kinds of souvenirs, and a big clock stands in the circular square outside the market, which is very eye-catching.The market is very lively every day, with people coming and going. There are many restaurants and food stalls inside and outside the market, selling authentic Vietnamese snacks at low prices.
sources.shortName: Top 18 Best Things to Do in Ho Chi Minh City

sources.snippet: Make sure that you bargain hard when you want to buy something at this market, it’s both expected and necessary to get a good price. Why it’s so awesome: This market is in the center of the city and is one of the most popular landmarks in Ho Chi Minh for shopping and eating. It contains a huge range of world-class street food vendors selling snacks and meals and you can find almost every type of souvenir in the market that you can imagine.
sources.shortName: 14 BEST Places to Visit in Ho Chi Minh (2024 Guide)

sources.snippet: Ben Thanh Market is a bustling market located in this old-school brutalist-style structure that is filled to the brim with people and shops selling all kinds of stuff, from street food to flip-flops. It is chaotic, crowded, and full of energy that is not seen anywhere else but here. That is why I recommend you stop by Ben Thanh Market in the evening and immerse yourself in the chaotic nature of Ho Chi Minh City and its inhabitants.
sources.shortName: 10 BEST Places to Visit in Ho Chi Minh City

sources.snippet: Sitting under a pillbox-style clock tower, Ben Thanh Market has been the city’s busiest and most important market for almost a century. Inside the main body of the market, a tight grid of aisles demarcated according to produce, teems with shoppers. If it’s souvenirs you’re after, a reconnaissance here will reveal conical hats, basket ware, bags, shoes, lacquerware, Da Lat coffee and Good Morning Vietnam T-shirts.
sources.shortName: 15 Unmissable Things To Do In Ho Chi Minh City

sources.snippet: Ben Thanh Market is one of the most important places to see in ho chi minh city from a shopping point of view. Visiting this place, you will be able to purchase cheap clothes, souvenirs, accessories, textiles, electronics goods and much more. In the course of the day time, the market sells fresh produce and groceries whereas after the sunset, this place completely transforms into a street food hub.
sources.shortName: 25 Places to Visit in Ho Chi Minh, Tourist Places & Attractions

sources.snippet: As the bustling heart of Ho Chi Minh City, Ben Thanh Market is a must-visit destination for those who have spent years shopping at some supermarkets and commercial centers. It would be an exhilarating experience to explore the Asian markets. Located in the central area of Ho Chi Minh City, Ben Thanh Market is a must-visit destination for anyone looking to experience the vibrant culture of Vietnam.
sources.siteName: Tourist Attractions in Ho Chi Minh | Vietnam Escape Tours
sources.shortName: Tourist Attractions in Ho Chi Minh

sources.snippet: For sightseers, the hot and hectic Ben Thanh Market is almost an obligatory stop, even if only to witness the crammed stalls and market chaos. The stalls are piled high with everything from local delicacies, fish, flowers, and tropical fruits to shoes, clothes, colorful candy, and souvenirs. The markets are also notorious for pickpockets, so make sure any valuables are secure and out of sight.
sources.shortName: 13 Top-Rated Tourist Attractions in Ho Chi Minh City

reviews.reviewText:
Ben Thanh Market, located in the heart of Ho Chi Minh City's District 1, is a bustling hub of activity and a cultural landmark. Known for its iconic yellow façade and clock tower, the market is a vibrant destination for both locals and tourists. It offers a wide variety of goods, including clothing, textiles, handicrafts, fresh produce, and street food.

The market is divided into sections, each specializing in different items. Visitors can find traditional Vietnamese clothing like Ao Dai, silk garments, and embroidered textiles. Souvenirs such as lacquerware, bamboo products, and handmade jewelry are popular choices. Food enthusiasts will enjoy the selection of Vietnamese coffee beans, dried fruits, spices, and local snacks.

Ben Thanh Market is also a great place to experience Vietnamese street food. From comforting bowls of pho to fresh fruit smoothies, the culinary options are diverse and delicious. The market operates from early morning until late at night, making it convenient for visitors to explore at their own pace.

While shopping, bargaining is a common practice, and visitors can often secure better deals by negotiating prices. The market's lively atmosphere, combined with its rich history and variety of offerings, makes it a must-visit destination in Ho Chi Minh City. Whether you're looking for unique souvenirs or simply want to immerse yourself in the local culture, Ben Thanh Market has something for everyone.

The Ben Thanh Market, is a bustling shopping destination in the heart of Ho Chi Minh City. Conveniently located in District 1, it is easily accessible and a must-visit for both tourists and locals.

The market has a well-organized yet chaotic layout, with sections dedicated to different products, including clothing, souvenirs, handicrafts, electronics, spices, and fresh produce. It offers an impressive variety of items, making it an ideal place for souvenir shopping or experiencing local flavors.

While the quality of products varies, many stalls sell authentic Vietnamese goods, from silk garments and lacquerware to high-quality coffee and local snacks. However, some items, especially branded goods, may be counterfeit, so buyers should be cautious.

Bargaining is essential here, as initial prices are often inflated, especially for tourists. A friendly but firm negotiation can help get the best deals. Overall, Saigon Market provides a vibrant shopping experience, perfect for those looking to explore Vietnamese culture through its diverse offerings.

Glad I planned my trip with HCMC as last destination. We travelled from North to south Vietnam. We kept solid 3 days for shopping and Ben thanh didn't disappoint me. This is crowded place mixed with good and not so okay sellers. Since I had enough time on first day I noted prices of various items from my checklist and shop numbers. Have to agree with other reviewers that you need to bargain a lot and prices are 3x. No AC. I visited other markets like Saigon square and central market too. Found this one cheaper.
Tip 1 - Go to this market early morning around 8:45-9 and you will get very good deal as sellers don't want to loose their first lucky customer.
Tip 2 - Ha Tam Jewellery store opposite of gate 5 gives you best usd exchange rate if you have new and crisp notes. Go here also early morning to avoid long queues.
Tip 3 - Buy in multiples like 3 or more pieces so sellers bring down the prices.
Tip 4 - Bargain with patience and smile.

Ben Thanh Market in Ho Chi Minh City generally receives positive reviews for its vibrant atmosphere, wide variety of goods, and food options. However, some reviewers mention that it can get crowded and that vendors can be pushy, especially during peak times. Bargaining is also a common practice at the market.

Here's a more detailed look at the reviews:

Positives:

Variety of goods:

Ben Thanh Market offers a wide array of items, including clothing, textiles, handicrafts, souvenirs, and local snacks.

Vibrant atmosphere:

Many reviewers appreciate the lively and bustling atmosphere of the market.

Food options:

The market features a variety of food stalls offering local specialties and street food.

Local culture:

The market provides a glimpse into Vietnamese culture and daily life.

Opportunities for bargaining:

Bargaining is a common practice at the market, allowing shoppers to potentially secure lower prices.

Negatives:

Crowds:

The market can become quite crowded, especially in the afternoons, which may be overwhelming for some visitors.

Pushy vendors:

Some reviewers mention that vendors can be persistent and pushy, making it difficult to browse at your own pace.

Overpricing:

The initial prices offered by vendors can be high, requiring bargaining to get a fair price.

Potential for scams:

Some reviewers have cautioned about the possibility of scams, such as inflated prices or misleading sales tactics.

sources.snippet: Right across the street from the Saigon’s Cathedral of Notre Dame, within the same city square, is yet another renowned landmark, the Central Post Office, that began construction back in 1886. reviews.reviewText:
Review: Ho Chi Minh Post Office

The Ho Chi Minh Post Office is a remarkable historical site and a must-visit while exploring the city. Located in the heart of Ho Chi Minh City, this building stands out for its stunning colonial architecture and timeless charm. The combination of intricate details, high ceilings, and vibrant colors creates a nostalgic atmosphere that transports you to a bygone era.

During our visit, we sent five postcards to friends and family, which was such a fun and personal way to connect while traveling. The availability of a wide range of postcards was impressive, and we enjoyed browsing through the beautiful designs. Additionally, the post office has been cleverly developed to include souvenir shops and even options to book tours, making it a versatile stop for tourists.

One of the highlights was simply taking in the ambiance of the space, where history and functionality meet. However, the only downside was the lack of air conditioning, which made the interior quite hot during our visit. It’s worth preparing for the heat, especially if you plan to spend some time inside browsing or writing postcards.

Overall, the Ho Chi Minh Post Office is a fantastic place to explore, shop, and send unique mementos back home. It’s a memorable experience that combines culture, history, and a personal touch.🔥💪

The Saigon Central Post Office is a historic landmark in Ho Chi Minh City and one of its most popular photo spots. Built between 1886 and 1891 during the French colonial period, the building was designed by architect Alfred Foulhoux, though it is often mistakenly attributed to Gustave Eiffel. The post office’s stunning French colonial architecture features grand arches, intricate ironwork, and a beautifully designed interior with a large map of South Vietnam painted on the walls. Despite its historical significance, the post office remains fully operational, serving both locals and tourists. Its charm and historical importance make it a must-visit destination in the city.

The Saigon Central Post Office is a must-visit landmark in Ho Chi Minh City! This beautifully preserved building combines French colonial architecture with local touches, making it a stunning sight in the heart of the city. From the moment you step inside, you’ll be greeted by the grand interior, featuring high ceilings, ornate details, and large wooden counters.

Not only is it a working post office, but it also serves as a historical site and a popular photo spot. The building houses a few souvenir shops, offering a great opportunity to pick up local goods.

It’s a fantastic place to stop by if you’re interested in architecture, history, or simply want to see a slice of old-world charm in modern-day Ho Chi Minh City. The staff is friendly, and the atmosphere is welcoming.

Definitely worth the visit, even if you’re not mailing a letter! The Saigon Central Post Office is free to enter and explore, so there’s no admission fee. However, if you plan to use the post office services, such as mailing items, the fees will depend on the weight, destination, and type of service (standard, express, etc.). Additionally, if you’re purchasing souvenirs or postcards from the small shops inside, those will have their own prices.

If you’re just visiting to admire the architecture or take photos, you can enjoy the experience at no cost.

One of HCM/Saigon’s iconic landmarks, definitely worth a visit. If you have the practice of sending postcards back home. This is the place to be. They have a variety of postcards and stamps to purchase and proper counters to purchase stamps and post them out.

There’s also souvenir stalls where price wise is of tourist pricing.

It’s also walking distance to the Notre Dame as it’s just across.

The Saigon Central Post Office is a stunning piece of French colonial architecture. The building is beautifully preserved, with high vaulted ceilings. It’s a great spot for photos and history lovers. Inside, you’ll also find souvenir shops and local artwork. Highly recommended for first-time visitors to the city!

When I visited the Saigon Central Post Office, it honestly felt like stepping into a piece of the past 🕰️. The building was built back in the late 1800s during the French colonial era, and you can really see the European influence from the outside—yellow walls, pretty details, and old-school charm 🏛️.

Inside, it’s super cool. It kinda reminded me of an old train station with its high ceilings, vintage maps on the wall, and those classic wooden phone booths ✉️. There’s also a big portrait of Ho Chi Minh at the end of the hall that gives it that local touch.

When I was there, the place was packed with tourists 🧳. A lot of them were busy choosing postcards, writing sweet messages, and sending them off. It was so nice to see people enjoying something so nostalgic and personal in this digital age ✍️📮. The postcards themselves cost around 20,000 VND, and the postage was about 30,000 VND to Indonesia —pretty affordable for such a memorable experience!

Even though it’s still a working post office, it feels more like a chill, mini museum. It’s quiet (well, except for the buzz of visitors), pretty, and just has this timeless vibe. I loved wandering around, snapping photos, and soaking up the atmosphere 📸. If you’re ever in Ho Chi Minh City, this place is definitely worth a visit!

PS: I sent a postcard to myself from there, and it arrived about a month later. Totally worth the wait—it felt so special to receive something handwritten from a place I visited.

This post office is well preserved, and it's almost like traveling back in time. Though a bit crowded, it's conveniently close to coffee shops and restaurants, which is a plus for tourists. There are also souvenir shops inside, making it easy to find something to bring home.

Lovely late 1800s architecture. This was an empty space for a long time but about 5 years ago had postal services provided. It also has a lot of souvenir shops. Right next to the cathedral which is still being renovated.

placeMetadata.name: Saigon Opera House

sources.shortName: attractions Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City Region

sources.snippet: Also known as The Municipal Theatre of Ho Chi Minh City, the elegant Saigon Opera House, at the start of the famous tree-lined Le Loi Avenue, is eye-candy for architecture buffs - especially fans of the French colonial style. It was built as Opera de Saigon in 1897 by Eugene Ferret, a French architect, to entertain French colonists, and its striking facade echoes the style of the Petit Palais, which was built in the same year in Paris. After 1956, the building was used as the home of the Lower House assembly of South Vietnam and again became a theater in 1975, after the fall of Saigon.

sources.snippet: If you have a chance to go to Ho Chi Minh City, you certainly can’t take your eyes off the elegant architecture of the Saigon Opera House.Standing magnificently at the heart of Ho Chi Minh City is the Saigon Opera House, which is also known as the Municipal Theater. The building stands as one of the impressive sights in Saigon – both night and day. Saigon Opera House was built in 1898 by the French architect – Eugene Ferret, following the “flamboyant” style of the French Third Republic.

Designed by renowned architect Eugene Ferret, this ornate masterpiece was originally constructed in 1897 as a symbol of entertainment for French colonists. The opera house features an elegant facade reminiscent of the Petit Palais in Paris and is located at the beginning of Le Loi Avenue.
placeMetadata.address: 07 Công trường Lam Sơn, Bến Nghé, Quận 1, Hồ Chí Minh 710212, Vietnam

reviews.reviewText:
★★★★★

A magical night at the Saigon Opera House! I had the pleasure of experiencing Berlin in Light here, and it was absolutely mesmerizing. The stunning architecture of the opera house, with its grand French colonial design, provided the perfect setting for an evening of jazz and artistic brilliance.

The acoustics were fantastic, making every note feel rich and immersive. The ambiance was elegant yet welcoming, and the staff were professional and helpful. If you're in Ho Chi Minh City and love the arts, this is definitely a must-visit venue. Would love to return for another unforgettable performance!

Very ornate and beautiful. (Check out my review of the A O Show (“Bamboo Circus” - a must see event at this Opera House. I would recommend buying tickets online (we bought ours about 5 weeks ahead) to get ‘best seats’, however, a couple close to us on the front row say they bought their tickets the previous day from the front of the Opera House.

The Opera House is an architectural marvel located in the heart of the city, close to many other popular attractions. The area is bustling with social media content creators, dressed in beautiful outfits, capturing reels and photos. While we didn’t attend any shows at the Opera House, we took some pictures to admire its stunning exterior.

We went here to watch AO show on a Wednesday at 8pm. It was a fast ticketing entrance and had a free refreshing green tea. The architectural is so stunning. We sat near the stage but at some angle it is hard to see the right portion of the stage. It was cool to be in the theatre place. The temperature of aircon is fine and comfort rooms are well maintained. You may buy the tickets online.

sources.snippet: The History Museum of Ho Chi Minh City is a captivating destination that will transport you through time and unveil the rich tapestry of Vietnam's past, including its colonial era, the Vietnam War, and its cultural heritage. The museum provides a comprehensive exploration of the rich history and diverse civilizations that have flourished in Ho Chi Minh City, showcasing ancient artifacts and archaeological treasures. It offers valuable insights into the struggles, triumphs, and resilience of the Vietnamese people, particularly during their fight for independence and the enduring societal changes they have experienced.
sources.shortName: 15 Unmissable Places to Visit in Ho Chi Minh City

sources.snippet: In the past you might have heard of the Gia Long Palace or the Revolutionary Museum, but now, the same place is officially known as the Museum of Ho Chi Minh City or HCMC Museum. When my wife and I visited, on a weekday in the middle of the morning, it wasn’t busy at all (unlike the War Remnants Museum which was packed out), so it was nice to peacefully walk around and enjoy the exhibitions. Most of the displays show the history and making of Ho Chi Minh City, and also there are a number of Vietnamese culture exhibits as well.
sources.shortName: 23 Things To Do In Saigon (Ho Chi Minh City): Top Attractions!

sources.snippet: Near the Reunification Palace, the Ho Chi Minh City Museum occupies an impressive Neoclassical building, formerly known as Gia Long Palace, that was once home to the Cochinchina's governor. It's worth a stop for an overview of the city's history and a look at the grand architecture, which includes Oriental and European flourishes. The museum traces the city's past with exhibits on the struggle for independence, nature and archaeology, trade, village handicrafts, currency, and the culture of Saigon.
sources.shortName: 13 Top-Rated Tourist Attractions in Ho Chi Minh City

sources.snippet: The Ho Chi Minh Museum was once a customs house for the French, famously named the Dragon House, which is now a museum dedicated to the erstwhile prime minister as well president of (then, Northern) Vietnam, Ho Chi Minh. It documents Ho Chi Minh's life through mementos, photographs, and official letters, providing a glimpse into the fascinating life of the founder of modern Vietnam. Tours starting from ₹1,279
sources.shortName: 52 Best Things To Do in Ho Chi Minh City Vietnam 2025

sources.snippet: Hồ Chí Minh City Museum is a chronicled site and gallery in Hồ Chí Minh City (Saigon), Vietnam. The historical center is arranged at the edge of Lý Tự Trọng and Nam Kỳ Khởi Nghĩa boulevards, situated on 2 hectares of land, close to the Independence Palace. The 2-stunned castle building covers a territory more than 1700 m², utilizing established Baroque design with European and Oriental impacts.
sources.shortName: 25 Places to Visit in Ho Chi Minh, Tourist Places & Attractions

sources.snippet: History Museum of Ho Chi Minh City is the perfect place to explore the city's rich history and culture. The museum has over 40,000 artifacts and documents on display, showcasing the city's evolution from prehistoric times to the present day. It is housed in a beautiful French colonial building and contains exhibits that highlight the city's culture, architecture, and development over time.

sources.snippet: If you want to learn more about the history, culture, and tradition of Ho Chi Minh City, this museum is the perfect place to spend an afternoon. The museum extensively covers Vietnam’s fight for independence as well.

placeMetadata.generatedDescription: The Museum of Ho Chi Minh City is a vast space spanning 1700 square meters, dedicated to preserving and showcasing a wide array of antiques, artifacts, and historical evidence. With 10 rooms housing different collections such as Nature and Archeology, Administrative Saigon, Revolution from 1954 to 1975, and more, the museum offers visitors an immersive journey through the city's rich history. The building itself boasts a unique design that combines classical European style with Asian elements.
placeMetadata.address: 65 Lý Tự Trọng, Bến Nghé, Quận 1, Hồ Chí Minh, Vietnam

reviews.reviewText: I always love a good museum to visit when I go on holidays. And Vietnam doesn't disappoint when it comes to museums. Very well presented and educational. Worth a visit, can be a little crowded with teenage girls photo shoots in every door way and staircase. But still enjoyable to see.

Stepping into the Ho Chi Minh Museum feels like taking a journey through time. As you enter, you're transported to the past, surrounded by a treasure trove of historical artifacts, collections, and exhibits. The museum showcases a vast array of relics, each one telling a story of Vietnam's rich history and cultural heritage. From ancient relics to modern-day memorabilia, every exhibit offers a fascinating glimpse into the country's past, making for a truly immersive and educational experience.

Visited on a weekday. surprisingly fewer people than I thought. Tickets were bought at the entrance + guardhouse.

Architecture is stunning and there are countless trinkets showcasing the Vietnamese history and culture etc.

It seems like it's a popular spot from weddings? When I was there, there was a wedding photoshoot happening at the main stairs hence not a lot of pictures there 😓

No air conditioning, but the areas were mostly sheltered and cool. There's only 2 floors to the Musuem, but the non-sheltered areas house the tanks & the planes.

Found the Museum to be pretty cool, worth the money and experience. Advice would be to stay there, take your time to leisurely look around the items, it really contains a lot of stuff from the past that's really interesting haha.

I visited the Museum of Ho Chi Minh City on a Saturday morning and was pleasantly surprised to find it wasn’t crowded with tourists. Instead, a few couples were there taking wedding photos, adding a charming and romantic atmosphere to my visit.

Though the museum may not have an extensive collection to explore, it is still a wonderful place for anyone interested in exploring both the past and present of this vibrant city.
It offers valuable insight into the city's rich history and the lives of the people who have shaped it. It's a place that invites reflection, learning, and a deeper understanding of the city itself.

Tickets are quite affordable and easy to purchase on-site, but keep in mind that payment is cash only. There’s also a small surcharge if you bring a camera.

Worth to visit here, affordable ticket price but beware there have some hard sell people outside the museum. Just don't answer their questions or greeting, otherwise you will end up for unnecessary things. All of us force to buy most expensive coconut here and one of my member's shoes force to wash without asking for permission. Come back for the museum, many things like the helicopter, plane, history, traditional clothes and Vietnam past currency can be see here. May take 1-2 hours to explore, and many people will likely take wedding photo here.

A fascinating glimpse into Vietnam’s rich history
The Museum of Ho Chi Minh City is well worth a visit if you're curious about the city’s past — from colonial times to wartime and post-independence.

The exhibits are thoughtfully arranged with a mix of photographs, artifacts, and memorabilia.

Highlights include sections on Vietnamese resistance movements, traditional culture, and the transformation of Saigon over the decades.

The architecture itself is beautiful — a French colonial building with character and charm.

Some signage could use more English translations for deeper understanding, but overall, it’s a great spot for history lovers and those wanting a break from the usual tourist trail.

This museum is amaaaaaaaazing. I have to words. Outside there are some heave army vehicles. When you enter in to the build in is like you enter in to a different world. The view is amazing and it feels nostalgic. There is also a bunker deep in the ground you should go. It feels creepy and mysterious. You need more than one hour. Go outside to the balconies and verandas and enjoy the view. 100% you need to go there.
Basic museum. Seems to be a very nice place for wedding photography; there were at least 2 wedding photographers when I was visiting the place.

sources.snippet: Like many of the museums in Ho Chi Minh City, one of the best parts of visiting is to admire the structure its housed in. Possibly one of the most elegant and well preserved pieces of architecture in the entire city (at least what I thought) is the Fine Arts Museum of Ho Chi Minh City, located just opposite the giant roundabout from Ben Thanh Market. Inside the museum, you’ll discover a great collection of artwork, including many paintings, sculptures, and lacquerware, that span the history of art in Vietnam.
sources.shortName: 23 Things To Do In Saigon (Ho Chi Minh City): Top Attractions!

sources.snippet: Ho Chi Minh City Museum of Fine Arts is an impressive building that houses an extensive collection of fine art pieces from Vietnam and around the world. The museum's vast collection comprises more than 21,000 artworks, consisting of traditional paintings, sculptures, and contemporary pieces that depict the city's history and cultural heritage. The building itself is a work of art, with a mix of French colonial and traditional Vietnamese architectural styles.
sources.shortName: Places to visit in Ho Chi Minh City: Top popular attractions

sources.snippet: Why it’s so awesome: This art gallery is housed in a colonial building from 1929 that includes stained glass, lovely verandahs, and art from the modern and ancient past. Some of the artwork dates back to the 4th century and a lot of it was inspired by the war and its effects on Ho Chi Minh and Vietnam as a whole. What to do there: If you want to learn more about art in Vietnam, then this is the best place to visit in Ho Chi Minh.
sources.shortName: 14 BEST Places to Visit in Ho Chi Minh (2024 Guide)

sources.snippet: During your Ho Chi Minh City full day tour, visiting Ho Chi Minh City Museum of Fine Arts should be one of the top attractions on your bucket list. Fine Arts Museum, or Ho Chi Minh City Museum of Fine Arts, is one of the largest museums in Ho Chi Minh City. It  has witnessed the ups and downs of history as well as the rise of Ho Chi Minh City after the unification in 1975.
sources.siteName: Tourist Attractions in Ho Chi Minh | Vietnam Escape Tours
sources.shortName: Tourist Attractions in Ho Chi Minh

sources.snippet: The Ho Chi Minh City Museum of Fine Arts, also known as the Fine Arts Museum, is a prestigious cultural institution located in Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam. The museum was established in 1987 and is housed in a beautiful French colonial building that dates back to 1929. The building itself is an architectural masterpiece, combining French and Vietnamese design elements.
sources.shortName: 15 Unmissable Places to Visit in Ho Chi Minh City

sources.snippet: Located near Ben Thanh Market, Fine Arts Museum in Ho Chi Minh City is one of Vietnam's largest fine arts centers. The museum building formerly belonged to Mr. Hoa, a wealthy Chinese man during colonial times. The yellow-and-white building combining French and Chinese elements is a masterpiece and houses a variety of paintings and sculptures.
sources.shortName: 52 Best Things To Do in Ho Chi Minh City Vietnam 2025

sources.snippet: Ho Chi Minh City Museum of Fine Arts is located in the heart of Saigon. Not only famous for the paintings and sculptures, but the museum also attracts its visitors with outstanding architecture. It was built in 1934 with a combination of Asian and European architecture, designed by French architect Rivera.
sources.shortName: 10+ Best Places To Visit In Ho Chi Minh Vietnam

sources.snippet: Set in a grand colonial mansion, Ho Chi Minh City’s Museum of Fine Arts is worth a visit to view some of the country’s best relics from Cham and Oc Eo. The first floor hosts temporary exhibitions, while the courtyard out back is given over to artworks for sale.
sources.shortName: 15 Unmissable Things To Do In Ho Chi Minh City

sources.snippet: Ho Chi Minh City Museum of Fine Arts: Immerse yourself in Vietnamese art history at this beautiful museum. Housed in a former colonial mansion, the museum showcases a collection of Vietnamese art from the 17th century to the present day.

sources.snippet: Not only is the Ho Chi Minh City Museum of Fine Arts one of Saigon’s biggest museums, but it’s another historical building that makes the list of must-visit attractions.

placeMetadata.description: Classical to contemporary Vietnamese & foreign artworks on display in an elegant colonial building.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: The Ho Chi Minh City Museum of Fine Arts, housed in a historic French colonial building dating back to 1929, is a prominent venue showcasing an impressive collection of Vietnamese and international art spanning from the 4th century to the early 20th century. Originally the residence of Chinese merchant Hui Bon Hoa, this museum officially opened its doors in 1991 and has since become a popular tourist attraction in Saigon.
placeMetadata.address: 97 P. Đức Chính, Phường Nguyễn Thái Bình, Quận 1, Hồ Chí Minh, Vietnam

reviews.reviewText: Didn’t really see this on many guides to Ho Chi Minh but would definitely recommend if you like art museums. Interesting and beautiful building (lots of people there just to take photos standing outside). Good variety of work. Only had an hour and half but could have spent more time wondering round at a slower pace. And as not as popular as other tourist spots was relatively quiet so no rushed atmosphere.

Overall I liked the place, definitely worth the ~$1.5 entry fee. Some rooms have AC, I think that's more to preserve the work than cool the guests.

Lots of beautiful young people come here to take photos of themselves, which is in stark contrast to the intent of an art gallery, to appreciate artists and their work. The lighting was a major let down, lots of the spotlights didn't work which meant some of the art had lopsided lighting.

Best part was the lower room of building 2, which seems to entirely house work from the last few years. Interesting that there wasn't any of the vapid youth in this area. Some of the art down there was incredible, at least to my tastes.

The museum building is a colonial-era mansion. There are exhibits both outside and inside. There are collections of both ancient and modern art. Overall, a very interesting museum, and it's nice that it's full of young people! Absolutely worth a visit!

Nice place. Has a great collection, and well categorized sections for people with different interests. A good place for young learners to learn about Vietnamese visual arts mostly. Would recommend to improve the lights of a few galleries as those create high glare on the glasses of the artworks or texts, which makes a bit difficult to understand from a distance. Nonetheless great place and a place I would recommend for the art lovers to visit.

Super nice place! could be a bit more preserved but you see that there is an effort on make everything as good as possible. You dont get to see much museums with modern art in asia, so this definitely worths the visit. You can quickly get a ticket at the door, and its around 1,50 dollars.

Nice museum, good for understanding historical background and culture. Main idea of most expositions is reflecting on war & peace. But too many people doing photoshoots, they are literally everywhere and sometimes behaving weird like touching paintings etc

Highly recommended to anyone to visit!!!
Located in district 1, the museum is lovely from outside. It was used to be one of the most richest guy’s house in Sai Gon back to the past. House with 99 doors. There are 3 floors in total. Each of them show either paintings or art works of numerous Vietnamese artists. Each of the architects very special and beautiful. We went here in the afternoon in weekday so it was not too crowded at all. Beautiful sunshine on the building. The balconies are special and good for taking photos as well. The ticket price is 30.000 (1.2$) per person. I would love to come back here again if I have a chance to visit Ho Chi Minh City

Just wonder about the security issues as there are no cameras and guards, how they gonna protect all the works

I’ve have visited this museum three times in 20 years. I am never disappointed. The gallery grounds are improving with a new building(s) dedicated to contemporary Vietnamese art.  The museum continues to hold one of the best sculpture-garden collections in South-East Asia.

placeMetadata.name: Notre Dame Cathedral of Saigon

sources.snippet: Saigon Notre Dame Cathedral Bacillica: Notre Dame Cathedral (Nhà Thờ Đức Bà Sài Gòn) is now the cathedral of Saigon Archdiocese. Before that, in the first phase of Tay Dang Trong (now Archdiocese of Saigon - Ho Chi Minh City), there was a first church, called Saigon Church on Road No. 5 (now Ngo Duc Ke street, District 1) and then the second Saigon church built on the banks of the Grand Canal. The Grand Canal, formerly known as the Canal Market or Charner Canal, is located right in the middle of Nguyen Hue Street, starting from Bach Dang Wharf, which runs straight to the West Commune, now the People's Committee of HCMC (86 Le Thanh Ton Street) District 1.
sources.shortName: Best Spots to See in Ho Chi Minh

sources.snippet: Probably not quite as grand as the Notre Dame de Paris, but nevertheless an important cathedral and landmark in Ho Chi Minh City, the Notre Dame Cathedral marks the center of the French colonial heritage in Saigon. They still hold services on Sunday if you’re interested, but if you just go to visit on any other day, make sure you arrive either in the morning from 8 am – 11 am or in the afternoon from 3 pm – 6 pm. When I went, I arrived right and noon lunchtime, and the gates were locked; So make sure you plan to visit during open hours so you can get inside.
sources.shortName: 23 Things To Do In Saigon (Ho Chi Minh City): Top Attractions!

sources.snippet: Saigon Notre-Dame Basilica is an important landmark in Ho Chi Minh City and a great example of the French colonial influences that spread across this area during the height of colonial days. The basilica is built in a beautiful Neo-Romanesque style of architecture with two iconic spires and a clock tower in the middle, all constructed using red bricks imported all the way from Marseille, France. It is a beautiful 19th-century piece of architecture that stands out from the rest of the city with its bold colors and intricate designs, both inside and outside.
sources.shortName: 10 BEST Places to Visit in Ho Chi Minh City

sources.snippet: As one of the four Basilicas in Vietnam, Notre-Dame Cathedral is considered an architectural masterpiece, contributing to the urban face and marking the formation and development of Saigon urban. Although it has undergone many impacts, Notre Dame Cathedral Saigon (also known as Immaculate Conception Cathedral Basilica) still retains its value, becoming a work not only of religious significance but also of great significance. is a symbol of the city, a tourist destination that any visitor to Saigon will not forget to visit.
sources.shortName: Top Attractions in Saigon (Ho Chi Minh City) that you do not want to miss (Part 1) - La Siesta Premium Saigon

sources.snippet: Situated at the center of Ho Chi Minh City, Saigon Notre Dame Cathedral is a symbol and one of the most famous tourist attractions in Ho Chi Minh City. The iconic architecture is over 150 years old, built by the French government during the French conquest of Vietnam in the late 19th century. Notre Dame Cathedral has been affected by the neo-Romanesque architectural style that is the reason why this building always brings its own unique quaintness but not found anywhere else.
sources.siteName: Tourist Attractions in Ho Chi Minh | Vietnam Escape Tours
sources.shortName: Tourist Attractions in Ho Chi Minh

sources.snippet: Saigon Notre Dame Cathedral is another iconic landmark in District 1 and is known for its stunning neo-Romanesque architecture. It was built in the late 19th century with red bricks imported from France and has been a popular tourist attraction ever since. The twin bell towers reach a height of 58 meters, making it one of the prominent places to visit in Ho Chi Minh city.

And with its two tall bell towers, it is definitely one of its most visible. The cathedral was originally built between 1863 and 1880 and was constructed on a site where a Vietnamese pagoda once stood.

reviews.reviewText: It was closed for public when we visited. We seen the surroundings. Also seems to be in renovation for the exterior so not much to check for photos now. Good that the post office is across the street!

Despite it is currently under renovation (April 19th 2025) and mostly covered with scaffolding, you can see parts of the Cathedral, testimony of the French presence period.
Not far from the Opera House and the Post Office.
You can also see the Cathedral from the uppest level of the Diamond Plaza Mall

The Notre Dame Cathedral of Saigon, built between 1863 and 1880 by French colonists, is a key landmark in Ho Chi Minh City. Featuring Romanesque architecture with a striking red brick facade and twin bell towers, it was constructed to serve the French Catholic community and remains a symbol of Vietnam’s colonial past. We had seen its beauty online, but unfortunately, due to renovations, the church was completely covered, leaving nothing visible. Despite our bad luck, we still managed to take a few pictures to capture the moment. Later, we hoped to enter inside to pray, but once again, luck wasn’t on our side. The watcher informed us that a function was taking place, and tourists weren’t allowed to enter.

placeMetadata.name: Independence Palace

sources.snippet: If you are going on a walking tour around Ho Chi Minh City, you will likely pass the Independence Palace, a brutalist-style building considered to be the place where Vietnam unified itself. It was here that a tank crashed through the gate, bringing an end to the Vietnam War. This place is more about the history and how significant it is to the Vietnamese people than the beauty of the architecture, and you will really appreciate the place more if you visit it with a local who can tell you all about the history of the palace.
sources.shortName: 10 BEST Places to Visit in Ho Chi Minh City

sources.snippet: Now a museum, but still used for official government meetings and events, the Independence Palace was the former home of the president of South Vietnam during the Vietnam War. After buying a ticket you can then go inside, and walk around a few of the floors to see all sorts of rooms including meeting rooms, dining rooms, and lounges that are fit for royalty. Every room and space within the Independence Palace is still furnished with original chairs and tables.
sources.shortName: 23 Things To Do In Saigon (Ho Chi Minh City): Top Attractions!

sources.snippet: Palace and exhibit “From Norodom Palace to Independence Palace 1868-1966”: 65.000 VND/adult (from 16 & above), 15.000 VND/child. The Independence Palace, also known as the Reunification Palace, holds immense historical significance as a prominent landmark in Ho Chi Minh City. This historic building served as the official residence and workplace of the President of South Vietnam during the Vietnam War era, witnessing pivotal moments in the country's history.
sources.shortName: 15 Unmissable Places to Visit in Ho Chi Minh City

sources.snippet: Independence Palace, also known as Reunification Palace, is a historic building located in District 1. It was the residence and workplace of the President of South Vietnam during the war and has stood witness to many significant events in the country's history. The palace has been preserved in its original state, with period furnishings and decorations, offering visitors a glimpse into the country's turbulent history.
sources.shortName: Places to visit in Ho Chi Minh City: Top popular attractions

sources.snippet: Designed by architect Ngô Viết Thụ, this property was once the home and workplace of the President of South Vietnam. In 1975, a North Vietnamese tank crashed through the main gate, effectively bringing the controversial Vietnam War to an end. Today, Independence Palace, also sometimes called the Reunification Palace, is a historic landmark that appears almost frozen in time.

sources.snippet: The cathedral area clearly shows the impression of Saigon as it is surrounded by skyscrapers and other modern buildings as well as many other famous places of the city such as Dong Khoi Street and Independence Palace. In front of the church, there is a small park and statue of Our Lady – the symbol of peace and happiness.

This architectural gem showcases South Vietnamese modernist design from the 1960s and offers visitors an immersive experience into its storied past. As you wander through its five floors, you'll encounter fascinating sights such as a recreation room and a bunker basement filled with vintage communication devices like phones and radios, alongside tactical maps that tell tales of strategic planning during tumultuous times.

reviews.reviewText: Definitely worth checking out if you’re in Saigon. Lots of historical information throughout the museum. Everything is immaculately well kept. I explored this place solo and had a great time checking out the displays and learning about the significance of each room. The underground basement for radio communication was a cool bonus I didn’t know about.

sources.snippet: Like the Ben Thanh, the Binh Tay Market offers a lot of a little of everything, including fresh produce and local handicrafts. The Binh Tay Market is located in Saigon’s Chinatown area and is actually a distribution hub for many of Saigon’s clothing and food items, so visitors may discover that some of the items available in the hundreds of the market’s stalls may only be for sale to wholesalers. Visitors who arrive at the Binh Tay Market early in the morning may get a chance to peruse the fresh food items that are available in the outdoor “wet market,” including fish and produce.

sources.snippet: Binh Tay Market: Binh Tay Market is a market in District 6, Ho Chi Minh City, located in an area called Cho Lon, so it is often called informally itself as Cholon. Binh Tay Market is located in a campus of 25,000 m2, located between 4 Thap Muoi - Le Tan Ke - Phan Van Khoe - Tran Binh roads. This market has a rectangular surface, 12 gates (both main and secondary) and is designed in Asian architecture.

sources.snippet: But I actually found Binh Tay Market to have better prices, be a more local experience, and I overall enjoyed visiting it more than Ben Thanh. Binh Tay Market is one of the major official markets, located in the Cholon area of Ho Chi Minh City, what is Chinatown. It has a similar feel to it as Ben Thanh, and even many of the products that are sold – from clothes to food – are basically quite similar.

sources.snippet: Binh Tay Market, called Cho Lon Moi or New Market is one of the main local markets across Ho Chi Minh City. It is a crowded place with more than 2000 shops divided into distinct sections, kitchen basics and leather goods being available in plenty.

reviews.reviewText:
Did not get to fully explore this market as much as I wanted to but got measured at the first vendor on the right when you enter from the main entrance for an ao dai. The fabric including the labor to make my ao dai cost just under $35 USD.

I also went upstairs to purchase more clothing and appreciate the vendors for not being too pushy or pressuring me to buy stuff compared to Ben Thanh Market’s vendors so I bought a lot of clothing here. They were nice when bargaining and fair with their prices after we negotiated. I told the vendors I would gladly return to give them my business again. Next time I come, I would like to see the other side of the market and try the food.

The stalls are very packed with wholesale merchandise and closely side by side, not much space to move around and see or buy stuff. The stall vendors also like not interested to sell to walk-in customers as they mainly sell in large quantities to smaller resale retailers, mainly goods from china. Also very stuffy and hot, there is also a line of stalls selling food and drink.
June 2025: local market with prices half of the touristy Ben thanh market. Took a bus ride from near Ben thanh market to binh Tay and the ride itself was a treat!
Great area to explore. Especially upper section. I wouldn’t eat anything or buy anything just good to venture around lots of cool attractions around that area
This is a mixture of wholesale and public vendor. No bargaining for most purchase cos they claim that it's wholesale price. Its a big market with food, dry produce, clothing, shoes and many more.

Local market with few tourist means you have more normal prices..
Busy place, central coutyard, toilets available if necessary.
Nice market.

Was glad I was able to include this market in my itinerary this time. You can find all sorts of dry foods, snacks and clothing, bags and shoes. I bought a hand carry bag for which the price was unbelievably reasonable.

placeMetadata.name: Giac Lam Buddhist Temple

sources.snippet: Believed to be the oldest temple in HCMC (1744), Giac Lam is a fantastically atmospheric place set in peaceful, garden-like grounds.
sources.shortName: attractions Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City Region

sources.snippet: The temple was built by an Chinese overseas named Ly Thuy Long who contributed money to build in 1744 and became the ancestral home of the Lam Te sect, Vietnamese Buddhism. Structures and Buddha statues layout style based on the ancient pagoda of South Vietnam. The system of envelopes and diaphragms are delicately carved, elaborately conveying the wishes of an elegant, happy and harmonious life through the images of apricot flowers, bamboo branches, cranes, custards, etc.

reviews.reviewText:
A Serene Escape in Ho Chi Minh City
Giac Lam Buddhist Temple is a peaceful haven that offers a beautiful blend of history, culture, and spirituality. As one of the oldest temples in Ho Chi Minh City, its architecture and atmosphere exude timeless charm.

The temple grounds are impeccably maintained, with lush gardens and towering Bodhi trees that create a tranquil environment. The main pagoda is stunning, adorned with intricate carvings and colorful murals depicting Buddhist teachings. Climbing the stupa provides breathtaking views of the surrounding area, a must for any visitor.

The welcoming monks and staff make the experience even more special, offering insights into the temple’s history and practices. Whether you're seeking a quiet moment of reflection or simply exploring the city's cultural heritage, Giac Lam Temple is a must-visit.

Don't forget to take a moment to admire the large Buddha statues and light an incense stick for good luck. Highly recommend for anyone visiting Ho Chi Minh City!
One of the oldest temple in Saigon. Not well maintained. Only the roof and the wooden columns are still authentic. Wall color not nice anymore. Still worth a visit.

Tho a little further outside the city centre, it is a nice Buddhist complex of pagoda, temple and statues, you can walk up the pagoda for very ncie views, I guess cuz of the location it was very empty & peaceful giving u plenty of space to discover the place

This is an interesting temple complex well worth a look and you can walk to the top of the tower for a stunning view of the city from the terrace. You have to scramble through a low window to get to the terrace so not for the feint hearted but the views are great
For me, like an european, it was an amazing and very interestin place, about belives, culture, customs
Very old temple with original statues and architecture. However, new architecture and statues added without plan make it lose its sacred atmosphere.
Nice temple with a surprising statue inside !
It was a nice visit. If you are in the area, do visit.

placeMetadata.name: Bitexco Financial Tower

sources.shortName: attractions Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City Region

sources.snippet: Standing taller than any other building in Ho Chi Minh City, and towering to the sky, is a skyscraper that’s made to look like a lotus bulb, known as Bitexco Financial Tower. From a distance, or from the sky, it’s easily the most recognizable building in Ho Chi Minh City, for its tallness and for its modern design. There are a number of things you can do when you’re at the Bitexco Financial Tower, but by far the most popular attraction is to take advantage of the height of the building to get a view of the city.
sources.shortName: 23 Things To Do In Saigon (Ho Chi Minh City): Top Attractions!

sources.snippet: Bitexco Financial Tower is one of the few modern skyscrapers standing over 262 meters (861 ft) right in the center of the city. It is the second tallest in the city and the fifth tallest in the country. With 68 floors, the tower offers a great vantage point above Ho Chi Minh City, and there is a nice observation deck on the 49th floor called Saigon Skydeck where you will be able to have a stunning view of the sunset over the horizon across the span of the entire city.
sources.shortName: 10 BEST Places to Visit in Ho Chi Minh City

sources.snippet: Situated in the Bitexco Financial Tower in District 1, the Saigon Skydeck offers panoramic views of the sprawling metropolis. As the sun sets and the city lights up, the view from the observation deck on the 49th floor is nothing short of mesmerizing. There’s also an option to dine at the tower’s restaurant, providing a perfect blend of culinary delights and visual treats.
sources.siteName: The Planet D: Adventure Travel Blog
sources.shortName: 32 Best Things to Do in Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam

sources.snippet: Why it’s so awesome: This tower was designed by Carlos Zapata and reaches 68 storeys in the air and 262 meters. The building was designed to resemble a lotus bulb and there’s a sky deck on the 48th floor where you can take in the views of the city. What to do there: Try to get to the tower at sunset for amazing views of the city against the colorful sky.

reviews.reviewText:
Highly recommended. We went up to the 49th floor of the Sky-Line lookout. Fantastic views really giving an appreciation of how large Saigon is; with the Saigon River snaking through the city - a major shipping route.
So, visiting is definitely worth the 360 degrees view. There is also a brief history from when the tower was built and some about traditional Vietnamese clothes. Good photos; lots of the different landmarks in the city; and a bottle of free water when you get the ticket. It has it all.

This is definitely worth a visit as it's in the heart of the city, and you can spot many  city sights from the 360° view, including the Saigon Post Office, Ben Thanh Market, cafe apartment and Landmark 81 tower. The viewing platform is on 49th floor, just below the helipad.  It's about half the cost of going up the 81 tower and more central to the city. You get a bottle of water, and there are free binoculars to use.  There is a costume display at the top, and some information about the tower which is interesting. It wasn't busy when we went on a Friday afternoon.

Tickets are required to ride to the observation deck via a very fast elevator. The views are 360 degrees from the observation area. I would definitely go back for evening views now that I know you can see the entire city below. The pleasant surprise is that you can pick up a free bottle of water from the small gift shop counter on this area. This is definitely a must-do visit if you'd like to see a layout of the Saigon River and the surrounding city.

Bitexco Financial Tower is definitely worth a visit if you're in Ho Chi Minh City. The building itself is super impressive, and the views from the Saigon Skydeck are incredible. You can see the entire city and the river, which looks especially beautiful at sunset.

There’s also a cool vibe inside the tower with shops and restaurants. If you have time, grab a drink at one of the bars—it’s a little pricey, but the views are totally worth it.

It’s a great spot to take some photos, chill for a bit, and soak in the city from above. Definitely a highlight of my trip!

The photo edit for the souvenir isn't very smooth. The air inside is cool and chilly, and the staff are friendly. You get drinking water (booked via Klook). This is the 5th most iconic building in the world. A must-visit!

Definitely worth visiting, especially during the night time. You will see a stunning panorama of the city and a few surprises. The viewing deck is located on the 49th floor - 35 sec trip by the fast elevator. Definitely must see place!

Visited in the evening and no queue and no wait....  Access from the 4th floor where the lift takes you to level 49 for great 360 views.

Only had 30 minutes spare but was worthwhile

Was approximately £7

Loved the view from the top and affordable £8pp.
We were hoping for food or a bar but it is a quick walk around the 360° views and back down.

reviews.reviewText:
This stunning church in Ho Chi Minh, affectionately known as the 'Pink Church', is a breathtaking example of European-inspired architecture in Vietnam. Its picturesque design and soft pink hue make it a popular destination for locals and tourists alike. Unfortunately, during our visit, the church was closed, and we were unable to venture inside. Nevertheless, the exterior was still worth admiring, and we weren't alone – many local and foreign travelers had also gathered to appreciate its beauty.

One of the best things about visiting this church is that admission is free; you don't need to purchase a ticket to explore the surrounding area. Getting here is also convenient, as you can simply book a Grab ride to arrive at the church's doorstep. Plus, there are plenty of charming coffee shops nearby, offering the perfect spot to relax and take some fancy photos that are sure to impress your Instagram followers.

Tan Dinh Church, affectionately known as the “Pink Church,” is a notable landmark in Ho Chi Minh City, celebrated for its vibrant pink facade and intricate architectural details. Constructed in 1876, it stands as one of the city’s oldest and most significant churches. ￼

The church’s striking pink exterior, adorned with white and gold accents, makes it a unique and picturesque site.

As one of the oldest churches in Ho Chi Minh City, it offers a glimpse into the city’s colonial past and religious heritage.

Located near Tan Dinh Market, visitors can immerse themselves in local culture, exploring traditional Vietnamese goods and street food. ￼

Cons:
•	Limited Access: The church is primarily open to the public during mass times. Outside of these hours, access to the interior is restricted, which may disappoint visitors hoping to explore the interior. ￼
•	Crowded During Services: During mass, the church can become crowded, potentially affecting the experience for those seeking a peaceful visit.

Mass schedules are as follows:
Monday – Saturday:
•	5:00 AM – 6:15 AM
•	5:30 PM – 7:00 PM
Sunday:
•	5:00 AM – 6:15 AM
•	7:30 AM – 9:00 AM
•	4:00 PM – 5:30 PM
•	7:00 PM
￼
Admission Fee: Free; donations are appreciated.

Dress Code: As a place of worship, visitors are advised to dress modestly.

Photography: While photography is generally allowed, it’s important to be respectful during services and avoid using flash.

The church itself is beautiful and stunning. I combined the visit with a stop in the Café opposite the church. Stunning view, chill vibes and wifi  there ;)

Nestled within a sprawling Chinese-style complex, this museum showcases an impressive array of artifacts and artworks spanning from prehistoric times to the modern era. As you wander through its serene courtyard, you'll encounter beautiful relics such as traditional clothing, musical instruments, and military items predating the Vietnam War. The displays also highlight various folk customs through intricate sculptures.
