reviews.reviewText: I was going to the botanical gardens and the museum is on the left of the entrance so I stopped in.  First of all, the ticket price is ridiculously cheap, 30,000VND (under $1.50US).  Next, the place is much larger than it looks from the outside and filled with interesting and beautiful exhibits. The museum includes exhibits from 1,000 years ago to the Vietnam War, many of them including English explanations. There was a puppet show (extra fee) going on in a small theater in the museum as well as a beautiful garden in the center to sit in the shade and relax. I spent a very enjoyable hour and recommend stopping by.

This is a very interesting museum in Ho Chi Minh City, which looks back at the history of the region, and there is very little specifically focused on Ho Chi Minh City itself. Unlike the Presidential Palace and the War Museum, this museum is much quieter, and you can very well explore it at your own pace. There are many chambers to see and appreciate about the art and history of this region. Early after is the best time to go as it is quiet, but consider that in most of the chambers, there is no AC, so in hot days, it can be a bit of a challenge.

A Peaceful Walk Through Vietnam’s Past

We visited the History Museum of Ho Chi Minh City early in the morning, right when it opened  and that turned out to be the best decision. The place was peaceful and nearly empty, allowing us to explore without any crowds. By the time we left, more visitors had started arriving, so if you prefer a quiet and calm atmosphere, definitely try to go when the doors first open.
The museum is beautifully arranged, guiding you step by step through the fascinating history of Vietnam. From ancient civilizations to more recent events, each section flows naturally into the next. We especially enjoyed the displays on ancient wars, traditional weapons, and the evolution of Vietnamese culture. Seeing swords, armor, and other artifacts up close gave us a deeper appreciation of the country’s resilience and rich heritage.
What really stood out was how everything is laid out in a way that’s easy to follow, even if you’re not a history buff. It feels like traveling through time  and learning about Vietnam’s past in one thoughtfully curated package.

The museum itself is housed in a beautiful colonial era building, and the peaceful garden outside adds to the charm. It’s not a massive museum, but it’s packed with meaningful displays and doesn’t overwhelm you with too much at once.
Overall, it was a highlight of our trip. Whether you’re just curious about Vietnam’s roots or already passionate about Southeast Asian history, this museum is well worth a visit. Just remember to go early for the best experience!

This place is definitely worth visiting to dive deeper into the history of Vietnam and gain a better understanding of the country’s unique character. It provides a solid foundation for exploring other locations, like the My Son Sanctuary. We spent about 1.5 hours in the museum, and it has a rich and diverse exhibition. Not far from the museum are the famous Jade Emperor Pagoda and a botanical garden, both of which are worth checking out if you're in the area.

sources.snippet: Tao Đàn Park, also known as Tao Dan Park, is a popular and vibrant urban park located in the heart of Ho Chi Minh City (Saigon), Vietnam. The park is named after a Vietnamese poet and intellectual, Nguyen Khoa Diem, who is also known by his pen name Tao Đàn.

sources.snippet: The perfect getaway from traffic noise, Tao Dan Park features 10 hectares of beautiful Sao Den trees and walkaways to revitalize you. The park is filled with locals exercising, and also houses a sporting club that draws children to it. A well-known bird cafe inside Tao Dan attracts numerous bird owners to relax with their pets.

sources.snippet: Spread over 10 hectares in District 1, Tao Dan Park is a green oasis in the urban jungle. A limited number of benches to sit on. There is a small temple and a statue in the center of the park. Not much else to see and there was a lot of construction going on when I was there in early Feb so most of the park grounds were very unattractive.

A Peaceful Oasis in the Heart of Saigon

Tao Dan Park is a breath of fresh air amidst the chaos of Ho Chi Minh City. In a city where traffic is hectic and streets are perpetually crowded, this park offers an invaluable sense of tranquility. With its sprawling green spaces, towering trees, and shaded pathways, it’s the perfect escape from the urban hustle and bustle.

I spent countless hours here during my stay, relishing the serenity and natural beauty. What struck me most was the predominance of foreign visitors, particularly Europeans, enjoying the calm atmosphere, while many locals seemed to prefer the lively energy of Saigon’s bustling streets.

Whether you’re a jogger, a photography enthusiast, or simply seeking a peaceful retreat, Tao Dan Park is an absolute must-visit. A true urban oasis!

My photos are a little old but the park is a nice place to hang out. Kindergarten students also do activities here, as well as other people. There are many traditional and cultural statues, lakes, fountains, etc.

When we visited just after TET, everything Tet display was being taken down.  This made the park look like a shambles.  Besides this, there was nothing else to enjoy.  One bit of enjoyment was watching  to men playing football badminton very professionally.  We had never seen this ever before and informed it that it was very popular in Vietnam.   Another comolete inconvenience was that there was only one allowed access into the park because there were some form of security guards at all other entrances saying we had to walk completely around the park to gain further access.

sources.snippet: Dedicated to the Jade Emperor, one of the highest powers and deities in Taoism, the Jade Emperor Pagoda is one of the most important Taoist temples in Saigon. As soon as you set foot into the compound, the loudness of the road traffic outside drifts away, and you can immediately feel a sense of calm throughout the temple. The front courtyard is shaded by draping banyan trees, with a spattering of pigeons, and a cloud of incense smoke that burns both inside and outside the temple and sets the mood by making the entire area hazy.

sources.snippet: If you have a chance to visit Ho Chi Minh City, which is renowned for its active and modern beauty, you will be so surprised by a one-hundred-year-old pagoda nestled with high buildings and in a bustling commercial center, Jade Emperor Pagoda. As one of the most visited Ho Chi Minh attractions, the pagoda is a familiar religious place for local people as well as domestic and foreign tourists. The pagoda was built in the early twentieth century by a Chinese man named Luu Minh, who left China to live and do business in Vietnam.

sources.snippet: **Built in 1892, the Jade Emperor Pagoda, also known as the Tortoise Pagoda (Chùa Phước Hải Tử) is dedicated to a pantheon of mythical Chinese-Vietnamese divinities in a mixture of Taoism and Buddhism. This pagoda was an important meeting place for Chinese secret societies that hoped to overthrow the Manchu Dynasty in Beijing. One of the most colorful pagodas in Ho Chi Minh City, it is filled with statues of various divinities and heroes.

The Jade Emperor Pagoda, known locally as Chùa Ngọc Hoàng, is a historic temple situated at 73 Mai Thị Lựu Street, District 1, Ho Chi Minh City.
Free parking inside the temple
Open: 07:00 - Close: 18:00

Constructed in the early 20th century, it was originally established by a Chinese man named Lưu Minh, also known by his religious name Lưu Đạo Nguyên. Lưu Minh, a native of Guangdong, China, was a practitioner of Minh Sư Đạo—a sect that advocated for the restoration of the Ming dynasty and opposed the ruling Qing dynasty. He built the temple both as a place of worship dedicated to the Jade Emperor (Ngọc Hoàng Thượng Đế) and as a clandestine meeting spot to plan efforts to overthrow the Qing dynasty.  ￼

In 1982, the temple came under the administration of the Vietnamese Buddhist Association when Venerable Thích Vĩnh Khương took over its management. Two years later, in 1984, it was officially renamed Phước Hải Tự, though it continues to be popularly referred to as Chùa Ngọc Hoàng.  ￼

The pagoda is renowned for its distinctive architectural style, which reflects Chinese influences. It has become a significant spiritual destination for both locals and tourists, who visit to seek blessings related to fertility, love, and overall well-being.  ￼

In 2016, Chùa Ngọc Hoàng gained international attention when then-U.S. President Barack Obama visited the temple during his official trip to Vietnam, highlighting its cultural and historical importance.

Today, the Jade Emperor Pagoda stands as a testament to the rich cultural tapestry of Ho Chi Minh City, embodying both historical significance and spiritual reverence.

Also because this pagoda is small and if you visit here in Lunar New Year you have to be very careful about your belongings to avoid getting pickpocket.

One of its notable moments in recent history was when President Barack Obama visited in 2016, which brought even more international attention to this spiritual site.

reviews.reviewText:
The Ho Chi Minh City People's Committee Building is one of the most beautiful landmarks in the city and a true architectural marvel. While the building itself is not open to the public, its grandeur and historical significance make it a worthwhile stop on any city tour.

This French colonial-style structure, built in the early 1900s, showcases intricate detailing and elegant proportions. The bright cream-and-yellow façade, with its arched windows and ornate decorations, is picture-perfect, especially when illuminated at night.

Standing in front of the building, you’ll find a statue of Ho Chi Minh, Vietnam's revered leader, in a peaceful garden setting. The combination of the statue, the manicured greenery, and the building in the background creates a scene that is both picturesque and meaningful.

Although you can't go inside, the building is a great spot for photography and a moment of reflection on the city’s history. The surrounding area is also lively, with cafes, restaurants, and shops that make it easy to spend time here.

Definitely a must visit.

We weren’t able to go inside but the streets are wide and lots of photo angles available.

High end branded stores line up the sides.

And the opposite side of the cityhall leads up to a river.

The apartment coffee bldg is also very near this place.
A very unique architecture style. An amalgamation of Western and the Eastern style. Well lit in the night makes it a an memorable lane to walk through

The Ho Chi Minh People’s Committee Building is a beautiful spot with classic French colonial architecture, making it a popular attraction. There’s a long street leading up to the building where you can take a pleasant walk. At night, the area comes alive with street shows and lights, creating a lively atmosphere. You can relax, people-watch, or simply enjoy the vibrant surroundings. It's a must-see if you’re exploring the city at night, and a great place to take in the unique architecture and local energy.

We had the privilege to visit this French architecture city hall during this special holiday of the Reunification day ‘23 in which the city opened for visitors domestically and internationally for the very first time. Quite nice and well reserved given that it is still served as the office building for the current government and administration of the city. Of course this is nothing compared to Versailles and other French world class building and architecture but I’m glad that Saigon manages to keep this building in such good condition.

This is a colonial style building made as per french architecture. This serves as the people's commmittee government building in Saigon. This building is popular as a tourist attraction in the city of Ho Chi Minh City. Visitors can explore the building from outside. There is a mini garden in front of this building and it adds a elegant look to this building.

Ho Chi Minh City People's Committee building (web site) was the city hall during French colonial era. Our guide calls it 'the City Hall', now a landmark in the city.

It's not open to the public.

The area is busy with traffic, pedestrians and tourists. Rex Hotel to one side (hosting luxury brands) and more luxury brands on the other side. In the middle, is a statue of Ho Chi Minh, who is widely respected.

After victories over conquests in Southern Vietnam, in 1870, the French drafted a plan to build an office for municipal council of Saigon at Kinh Lớn ("Big Canal"). However, the area was too muddy to lay a foundation hence halting the project. Until 1898, after the canal was covered to be made into Charner Boulevard, the French finally broke ground for the building. 1.5 million francs was approved for the project.The building was a difficult project that took 11 years to finish.
The building was opened in 1909 by the French Indochina governors-general to celebrate 50 years of French presense in Saigon. The building was named L'hôtel de ville ("Municipal Hall"), while the Vietnamese locals generally called it Dinh xã Tây ('French municipal palace') or Dinh đốc lý or ('mayor's palace').

During the Vietnam War, the building was used by the city of Saigon government under South Vietnam and was renamed Tòa đô chánh Sài Gòn or Tòa đô sảnh ('Saigon mayor's hall').
Since the communists’ conquest of Saigon in 1975, the building has housed the Ho Chi Minh City People's Committee and Ho Chi Minh City People's Council. The building was renamed as it is now.
On April 29 and 30, 2023, to celebrate the Reunification Day, the building was opened to public for the first time.

Directed by architect Fernand Gardè, the hall design took inspiration from the town hall of Paris and resembles the bell towers of northern France - a rising point-shaped tower accompanied by two adequate symmetrical attic towers and shorter but long blocks on the sides. The center tower includes a clock and at its peak a flag pole. Another storey was then built on top of the blocks in the 1940s.
The design of the building is a fusion of multiple classical architectural streams like Renaissance, Baroque and Beaux-Arts, as seen on its with Baroque and Rococo decoration, Art Nouveau iron doors, Corinthian columns and domic entrances. The entire front facade is sculptures of wreaths, ylang ylangs and men in Phrygian cap, reflecting the architecture of the French Third Republic. With so many inspirations taken from, the building was deemed by some as "a woman with too much jewelry".

On the facade of the building, three sculptures of Marianne are placed in the middle of the pediments. She is the national personification of liberty, equality and fraternity of the French Republic.

The left sculpture shows the figure of Marianne seating on a podium. Her left hand is placed on a vase pouring water while her right hand holds a ship's rudder. She wears a laurel wreath on her head with some laurel decoration on the background. Below the figure is the wheat motif, a Caduceus, and a scythe.
The laurel wreath usually implies victory, while the Caduceus is Hermes's staff, often recalled as the symbol of commercial activity or negotiation. The appearance of the ship's rudder is believed to represent the strength of commerce and trading.The sculpture is an indication of equality.

At the center of the facade, under the bell tower lies a sculpture depicting a goddess and two children and two lions. The child on the left holds a long staff pointing at the female figure, while the boy on the right is stepping between two fierce lions. Marianne is most prominent with her taking-off-Phrygian-clothes posture, similar to the image of half-naked Marianne in the Liberty Leading the People painting. Her position also suggests that they bravely lead each other out of danger and wilderness.
The theme of this sculpture could be liberty as the woman is trying to escape from the mess and wild, with her eye looking up, fulfilled with hope and prospect. Out of the three sculptures, this one is also the most active form of Marianne, as she does not rest but moves vividly. This central sculpture stands for fraternity.

As a family of 4 travelling the world 🌎
Vietnam is a must see

Ah, the Ho Chi Minh City People's Committee building, a true architectural gem nestled in the heart of Saigon. Picture this: it’s the early 20th century, and the French colonial rulers, with their flair for grandeur, erect the Hôtel de Ville de Saigon. Fast forward to the tumultuous '60s, this elegant edifice, with its intricate façade and majestic clock tower, becomes the backdrop for one of the most dramatic moments in Vietnam’s history.

In '63, right in front of this iconic building, a group of Buddhist monks staged a protest that shook the very core of the nation. Their peaceful demonstration against the government’s oppressive policies drew international attention, casting a spotlight on the plight of the Vietnamese people. This wasn’t just a protest; it was a catalyst for change, a moment that would echo through the annals of history.

Today, this building stands not only as a testament to French architectural prowess but also as a silent witness to the resilience & enduring spirit of the Vietnamese people.

It’s a place where the past and present collide, offering a profound reminder of the city’s rich, albeit tumultuous, heritage.

Quite the tale, wouldn’t you agree?

Ho Chi Minh City Hall, officially called the Ho Chi Minh City People's Committee Head Office, is the city hall of Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam. Since communist conquered Saigon in 1975, the building has housed the Ho Chi Minh City People's Committee, Ho Chi Minh City People's Council and Ho Chi Minh City People's Court, respectively.
The building is popular for its photo opportunities. Tourists can take photographs outside and many people choose to do this at night when the building and its milieu are lit up.

📍People’s Committee of Ho Chi Minh City

The People’s Committee of Ho Chi Minh City, also known as the Ho Chi Minh City Hall, is a governmental building located in District 1 of Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam. It serves as the headquarters for the city’s government and administration. The building is an iconic landmark in the city and is often visited by tourists who admire its French colonial architecture and its significance as a symbol of local governance. Additionally, the area around the building, including Nguyen Hue Walking Street and the nearby parks, is a popular spot for locals and tourists to relax and enjoy leisure activities. It sounds like the People’s Committee of Ho Chi Minh City building is a popular spot for taking photos.

Originally built in the early 20th century by French colonial rulers as the Hôtel de Ville de Saigon, the Ho Chi Minh City People's Committee building is an architectural gem in Saigon. With its intricate façade and majestic clock tower, this elegant structure became the backdrop for a pivotal moment in Vietnam's history.
In the 1960s, a group of Buddhist monks staged a powerful protest against government oppression in front of this iconic building, drawing international attention and sparking change.
Today, it stands as a testament to French architectural influence and a witness to the resilience of the Vietnamese people, embodying the city’s rich and complex heritage.

This is the absolute most AMAZING puppet show I have ever seen. You don't have to understand the language to understand the story line. The theatrics and vocals are beyond compare.

Food/drinks were not recommended to consume if you’ll bring one. Mostly are foreigners though the language used was in Vietnamese. No need to learn the Vietnamese because mostly are in actions and sounds. Light and choreography of the puppets were excellent. Worth your money. We bought our ticket online and claimed the physical ticket thru one of the staff in front of the kiosk. Souvenirs were sold outside after the show and it was not that expensive especially the toys and post cards. Definitely all souvenirs were unique and you can buy it only at that place.

OMG! This is so good, kids loved it.
The show is only in local language but the way it’s played, you would understand the concept. People managing those puppets are superb!
Definitely worth watching

from the moment i arrived, i was warmly greeted by the friendly and helpful staff at the door who kindly directed me to the toilets and assisted with ticket collection.

i couldn’t help but wonder how they managed to perform with puppets in the water, and they satisfyingly revealed the secret at the end of the show!

it was such an amazing experience, and I’d definitely bring more friends along if I get the chance to go again!

sources.snippet: A few kilometres off Highway 22, in the town of Long Hoa, sits the enigmatic Cao Dai Great Temple, or Cathedral, of the Holy See of Tay Ninh. A grand gateway marks the entrance to the grounds of the structure. At first sight, the temple seems to be subsiding but your initial impressions are more likely to be dominated by what Graham Greene described as a “Walt Disney fantasia of the East, dragons and snakes in Technicolor”.
sources.shortName: 15 Unmissable Things To Do In Ho Chi Minh City

sources.snippet: This religion integrates other major religions into its doctrines, which is why the mix of religious statues inside the temple are the main draw for tourists. Why it’s so awesome: Cao Dai is a relatively new religion established in Vietnam in the 20th century. It’s a monotheistic religion that integrates aspects from all the major religions within its doctrines.
sources.shortName: 14 BEST Places to Visit in Ho Chi Minh (2024 Guide)

sources.snippet: Intrigued by the prospect of witnessing a religion that blends elements of Buddhism, Confucianism, Christianity, and Taoism?. The Cao Dai Temple offers a captivating glimpse into this philosophy. Imagine a technicolor spectacle - the temple's facade explodes with vibrant yellows, blues, and reds, each symbolizing a core tenet of Cao Dai.
sources.shortName: Top Things To Do & Must-See Attractions

sources.snippet: Combining elements of Buddhism, Christianity, Taoism, Confucianism and Islam, the Cao Dai Temple affords a colourful exterior. The interiors feature murals and symbols from all these religions.

sources.snippet: The temple took some 20 years to build and was finally completed in 1956. Inside you will find some ornate carved dragons but the real draw is the mix of religious statues here.

It serves as the focal point for the Cao Dai faith, a unique Vietnamese religion that blends elements of Taoism, Confucianism, Buddhism, Islam and Christianity. The temple's architecture is a blend of pagoda, cathedral and mosque styles. Visitors can witness the mesmerizing prayers of Caodaists during their visit.

reviews.reviewText: As a member of Cao Dai religion who just visited Thanh That Sai Gon for the 1st time together with my customer, I am surprised and proud of the way Cao Dai brethren welcome tourist visit our temple. Look at these cute little guides. They are intelligence and so much friendly.

Tour guide brought us here for a different aspect of the local temples. You will have to remove your footwear to enter and be split accordingly to gender. The females will enter by the stairwell on the left whilst the males will enter by the stairwell on the right. Devotes would dress in white.

Eclectic and charming place. Truly fusion religion. They even worship Victor Hugo as a diety here. I wonder if Neil Gaiman had this place in mind when he wrote The Graveyard Book and one of the ghouls in the story was The Author Victor Hugo....
Nice place to explore but unfortunately this morning they were busy preparing for funerals.

Well worth the pilgrimage from the centre of town, you will be rewarded with beautifully decorated rooms and halls, warm hospitality and an insight into this unusual and special religion; unique to Vietnam. Remember to wear long trousers or ask for a robe, and remove your shoes. Women use the left stair, men use the right. Enjoy the beautiful decorations and make sure to visit the towers at the top.
This is a must see. It is so beautiful and peaceful there. You will surely enjoy this.Go!

What an incredible experience! I found a staff member who invited me to look around the building. There were no signs so I didn't understand the history of the building, but I was blown away by the colours, concepts and craftsmanship. I was the only one in all five levels of the temple. It was wonderful to take 15 mins and just sit in the main room and just take it all in.
A congregant took us to view the prayer halls upstairs. Really interesting and beautiful Cao Dai temple.

sources.snippet: One of the drawbacks of taking Ho Chi Minh city tours by day is that the river can be smelly due to the waste that is disposed into the water, however the shorter city trips will also usually include a trip to the secret city canals where the locals live, thus giving you an authentic slice of real Vietnamese life. More popular are the longer day excursions on boats heading along the Saigon River to the Cu Chi tunnels along with a visit to the Mekong Delta. A boat trip to the Mekong Delta offers a fascinating insight into village life.

placeMetadata.name: Bui Vien Walking Street

sources.snippet: Known as the "Backpacker's District," Bui Vien Street is a central hub for budget-conscious travelers and adventurers. During the day, this vibrant area transforms into a haven for shoppers, offering a wide range of shops that cater to various tastes, from charming boutiques to well-known international brands. As the sun sets, Bui Vien Street comes alive with its dynamic bar scene.
sources.shortName: 15 Unmissable Places to Visit in Ho Chi Minh City

sources.snippet: The nightlife of Vietnam thrives in Bui Vien street in Ho Chi Minh. The street is full of cheap hotels, hostels, pubs, bars, restaurants, massage parlours as well as a few clothing and souvenir stores here and there. The area comes alive at midnight, with dance music buzzing out of the clubs and backpackers seated at various restaurants with a glass of beer.

sources.snippet: The heart of nightlife in Ho Chi Minh City, Bui Vien Walking Street in District 1 is Ho Chi Minh City’s most popular walking street. reviews.reviewText: This vibrant tourist attraction in Ho Chi Minh City is a lengthy street lined with an array of restaurants and bars, transformed into a dazzling spectacle every night through its mesmerizing illumination. As you stroll along, you might be surprised by the warm hospitality of locals, with some even offering you a complimentary drink or inviting you to take a seat. The street is abuzz with activity, featuring “sexy men and women dancers” that add to the lively ambiance, often accompanied by loud music that pulsates through the air. The nightlife here is truly unique, giving the impression that sleep is a distant concept in this area. It's an exhilarating experience that's definitely worth anticipating – the energy is electric, and the memories are waiting to be made.

🎶 A Chill Spot to Unwind After a Long Day 🍻

If you’re looking for a place to relax after a long day of work, this is a great spot. The music from the DJ is just right lively enough to set the mood, but not too loud like in a nightclub. You can still have conversations while enjoying the breeze with friends out on the sidewalk.

I really enjoyed sipping on a drink, snacking on tasty street-style food, and watching the busy street life go by full of good vibes and eye catching people passing through!

The prices are affordable, and the whole atmosphere feels relaxed and friendly.
It was definitely a fun and refreshing experience for me .  I’ll be coming back!

During the day, Bui Vien Walking Street is just like any other street in HCM City.

Eateries, cafes, spas, convenience stores, restaurants, hotels, etc. are busy with their usual day-to-day activities.

Locals and tourists alike are out on the street conducting their businesses, running errands, having their meals in the many eateries, people watching, etc.

The scenario changes dramatically after 7.00 p.m. when the street really comes alive with blaring heart-pounding music that instantly hiked up your mood and liven up the night.

It's the start of party time on Bui Vien Walking Street. The crowd on the street transforms, and you can see the  people starting to wear off the serious business-like and busy-looking faces to be replaced by a more casual, relaxed, calm and easy-going manner.

As the night progresses, the entire street is transformed into one huge party zone with the many clubs and bars coming alive, the sights of the alluring beautiful techno lights livening up the night with rainbow colours glittering and inviting everyone from party-goers and lonely souls to partake in a night of fun and revelry.

In my opinion, there is no other street in HCM City that can rival Bui Vien Walking Street at night in terms of party atmosphere and vibes. It is such a captivating, lively and enjoyable yet relaxing atmosphere.

I spent most of my 2 nights of my stay in HCM City in Bui Vien Walking Street enjoying my dinner with a glass of flavourful and rich iced Vietnamese black coffee at my favourite joint, 5 Boys, while watching the world go by.

Although I stayed at a hotel very close by to Bui Vien Walking Street, I do not feel disturbed or annoyed by the blaring heart-pounding music from the many clubs there nor did it cause me any sleepless nights.

I very strongly recommend tourists / visitors to HCM City to pay a visit to Bui Vien Street during the night at least once during your visit to this beautiful city.

To me, Bui Vien Walking Street did not disappoint, and I really enjoyed my time there having dinner while sipping the flavourful and rich iced Vietnamese black coffee.

Bùi Viện Walking Street is a must-visit spot when you’re in Ho Chi Minh City! The street really comes alive at night—full of energy, lights, music, and people from all around the world. It’s a great place to walk around, grab a drink, enjoy street food, and soak in the lively atmosphere.

There are tons of bars, restaurants, and clubs to choose from, whether you’re looking for a chill night out or want to party. Street performers and live music add to the fun vibe. It’s busy and vibrant, but also feels quite safe with lots of people around.

Perfect for people who love nightlife, trying local snacks, and meeting new friends. Just be mindful of your belongings—like in any busy area. Definitely an exciting experience you shouldn’t miss while in Saigon.

Bui Vien Walking Street in Ho Chi Minh City is a vibrant and lively destination that perfectly captures the energetic spirit of Saigon. Located in the heart of District 1, this pedestrian-friendly street offers a colorful mix of street food vendors, local shops, and cultural performances that create a welcoming and dynamic atmosphere for both locals and tourists. Visitors can enjoy a wide variety of delicious Vietnamese dishes and international flavors while exploring the bustling street filled with friendly faces and unique sights. Bui Vien’s lively ambiance and rich cultural vibe make it a must-visit spot for anyone wanting to experience the authentic, everyday charm of Ho Chi Minh City.

It's a vibrant attraction place for the tourists to enjoy songs with drinks and eat. Basically It's a long street which is covered with many bars and restaurants on both sides of street. There are many bars for enjoying a lot. A good place for releasing stress in ho Chi Minh city nearby the ban than Market.

placeMetadata.name: Cholon

sources.snippet: Cho Lon is the Chinatown of Ho Chi Minh City and the largest one across Vietnam. It is situated on the west bank of the Saigon River and spread over Districts 5 & 6. Cho Lon is renowned for its bustling markets, including Binh Tay Market, temples like Thien Hau Temple and Quan Am Pagoda, and street food stalls, local eateries, and restaurants serving authentic Chinese and Vietnamese cuisine.
sources.shortName: 52 Best Things To Do in Ho Chi Minh City Vietnam 2025

sources.snippet: Step into the vibrant heart of Ho Chi Minh City's Cho Lon, and you'll find yourself enveloped in a world where the past and present merge to create an experience that's as rich in history as it is in sensory delights. Known as the city's Chinatown, Cho Lon is a tapestry of cultural heritage, bustling markets, and culinary adventures that await your discovery.
sources.shortName: Top Things To Do & Must-See Attractions

sources.snippet: Back in the old days, the place where Cho Lon now sits was regarded as the city’s center of commerce, in comparison with District 1 – the center of administration.

placeMetadata.description: Cholon is Vietnam's largest Chinatown, where sprawling Binh Tay Market offers everything from fresh produce and seafood to fabric and lacquerware. Eateries and street food stalls selling Chinese-style noodles, roast pork, and salted duck eggs pack narrow lanes along with traditional herb stores. The 18th-century Thien Hau Temple holds a yearly festival to celebrate the birth anniversary of Mazu, goddess of the sea.

placeMetadata.name: Saigon Zoo & Botanical Gardens

sources.snippet: Saigon Zoo and Botanical Garden is the largest zoo in Vietnam with more than 1,000 animals and more than 2,000 species of plants and flowers. This is one of the ideal destinations not to be missed if you are traveling with children to help them become aware of the natural world. This place gathers many rare and precious animals from all over Vietnam such as lions, elephants, tigers, peacocks, giraffes, pythons, etc.
sources.shortName: Top Attractions in Saigon (Ho Chi Minh City) that you do not want to miss (Part 2) - La Siesta Premium Saigon

sources.snippet: Being the 8th oldest zoo in the world, Thao Cam Vien, or Botanical Gardens, is considered the largest zoo in Vietnam. You will find animals from every continent, like white tigers, lions, monkeys, crocodiles, and rare animals. In addition to the plethora of plants and ferns, it houses Butterfly and Flamingo Garden, Children's Garden, Orchid Greenhouse, Cactus Garden, and Animal and Plant Museum.
sources.shortName: 52 Best Things To Do in Ho Chi Minh City Vietnam 2025

sources.snippet: Clustered together in the same park, is both the Saigon Zoo and the Botanical Gardens. Instead of having to pay for both attractions, you just pay a single entrance fee and you can then walk around both. The zoo, that is the animals part of the zoo, is not so great – the animals don’t look too happy, and the cages aren’t set up very well – it could definitely use a major renovation.
sources.shortName: 23 Things To Do In Saigon (Ho Chi Minh City): Top Attractions!

sources.snippet: Saigon Zoo & Botanical Garden, also known as Thao Cam Vien, is a popular attraction located in Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam. Established in 1865, it is one of the oldest zoos in the world and covers an area of approximately 20.5 hectares. The zoo is home to a diverse collection of animals and plants, making it a great destination for nature and wildlife enthusiasts.

reviews.reviewText:
I recently visited the zoo, and overall, it was a pleasant experience. The place is quite spacious, with lots of greenery, which makes walking around very relaxing. It’s a nice spot to spend a few hours, especially if you enjoy being outdoors. They also have some interactive activities, like feeding the animals, which kids would really enjoy.

That being said, the zoo doesn’t have many rare or exotic animals—mostly common ones like elephants, deer, monkeys, tigers, and lions. But I understand that maintaining a zoo requires a lot of funding, so it’s not always easy to bring in more unique species. The animals seem to be taken care of fairly well, but some enclosures weren’t very clean and had a bit of a smell. It would be great if they could improve that part.

Overall, if you’re looking for a casual place to walk around and see some animals, this is a good option, especially for families with kids. Hopefully, with more support and investment, the zoo can continue to improve and create an even better experience for visitors!

We came here hoping to see the botanical gardens - the gardens here are nice but nothing very special - except there is a great variety of bonsai trees.  It is a lovely day out - we came on a Sunday and the family atmosphere was brilliant with music and circus performers.  The zoo - I'm not the biggest fan.  A lot of the animals looked very well cared for and very well but there were a few pacers.  We went on the big wheel here that was magnificent - a real treat and cost about 30,000 each.  The whole trip was fantastic value for money.  A really nice day out.

We recently visited the Saigon Zoo and Botanical Gardens in Ho Chi Minh City with our family and had a delightful experience.  The zoo is one of the oldest in the world and offers a blend of wildlife and lush greenery.

Tips:

Best Time to Visit: Arrive early to enjoy cooler temperatures and more active animals.

Amenities: Bring water and snacks, though refreshments are available on-site.

Accessibility: The zoo is centrally located and easily reachable by taxi or bus.

In summary, the Saigon Zoo and Botanical Gardens provided our family with an enjoyable and educational day out, combining wildlife, greenery, and cultural heritage in the heart of Ho Chi Minh City.

The entrance fee is affordable, and the location is convenient. It’s a great place to bring kids to pass the time.

There are many beautiful gardens for mothers to enjoy the flowers and greenery, plenty of animals to see, and a spacious area with playground facilities for children. It’s the kind of place where you can admire flowers, watch animals, and have fun at the playground all in one visit.

Each area has small vendor stalls where you can buy drinks and snacks. The restrooms are clean and convenient.

Highly recommended for families with kids!

There’s a reason this zoo isn’t very popular among tourists — the infrastructure could be better, especially for the animals. Overall, it felt more like pity than joy. If you suddenly have extra time to spare and can’t think of anything else to do, sure, why not? You won’t be too disappointed, but it won’t be the highlight of your trip either.

Overall, it was a great experience! The zoo is very spacious, making it a perfect spot for a family picnic. I was pleasantly surprised to find a mini amusement park inside — definitely a bonus for kids and those young at heart. What truly caught me off guard was the Natural History Museum within the zoo ground

This place was amazing! The animals were so cool (the giraffe was my favorite).

Not only were there tons of animals, but the trees and botanical garden was next level.

If you’re looking for a quick little day trip adventure, I highly recommend coming to this zoo. Perfect for all ages and very safe!

Saigon Zoo is one of those old-school spots in Ho Chi Minh City that hasn’t exactly been pampered in a while. The park feels a bit worn down, with some areas showing their age — faded paint, cracked paths, and benches that look like they survived a few storms too many. It’s not the fanciest zoo you’ll ever visit, but it has a certain raw charm that’s kinda nostalgic.

What really sets it apart, though, is the animal variety. Compared to the glammed-up amusement parks like Nha Trang’s VinWonders, Saigon Zoo has a surprisingly large number of animals packed into its space — from monkeys jumping around to peacocks strutting their stuff, and plenty of other critters. It’s like a little jungle right in the middle of the city.

The place is pretty clean considering its age, and the crowd is usually chill — mostly locals and a few curious travelers. There’s even a modest public restroom if you need it, though don’t expect anything fancy.

Best of all? The entrance fee is dirt cheap — just 2 bucks. For that price, you get a chance to see a lot of different animals and soak in a bit of old-school Saigon vibes. So if you’re up for a laid-back afternoon surrounded by animals, without the glitz and glam, this is your spot.

Despite many years of operation, the park has remained dedicated to maintaining and enhancing its exterior, ensuring that it continues to impress visitors with its well-designed and carefully decorated surroundings. The attention to detail in its lighting and decorations makes it a visually stunning destination after dark.

Inside the park, many carnival-style games and attractions are still active, with new activities and entertainment options added over time. These updates keep the experience fresh for returning visitors. However, despite these improvements, the promotional efforts and media outreach to attract more tourists have not been fully developed. placeMetadata.name: Thien Hau Temple

sources.snippet: The atmospheric 19th-century Thiên Hau Temple is one of the best places to visit in Ho Chi Minh City's Chinatown (ChoLon) and one of the oldest Chinese temples in the city. Dedicated to the Lady of the Sea, Thiên Hau, this evocative temple is visited by local worshippers, as well as tourists, and many of the materials used in its construction were brought from China. Clouds of incense billow in the air, candles flicker on altars, and shafts of sunlight pierce through the partial roof as you enter the green wrought-iron gates and stroll across the small courtyard.

sources.snippet: The temple is dedicated to Thien Hau, the protector of the sailors. Even if the temple isn’t really impressive from the outside, it is still known as one of the highlights of Ho Chi Minh City. As soon as you get to the inside, you will notice the smell of the incense sticks that are scattered throughout the temple and hanging from the ceiling.

My recent visit to Dam Sen Water Park was a delightful experience overall, marked by a clean environment, professional staff, and enjoyable rides. However, there were some concerns, particularly regarding the counter at the entrance, which marred an otherwise fantastic day.

**Cleanliness and Professionalism:** The water park boasts a commendable level of cleanliness and maintenance. The staff members are highly professional, courteous, and attentive, ensuring a pleasant and safe environment for all visitors. The rides are well-maintained, and the water quality is pristine, contributing to an enjoyable experience.

**Value and Attractions:** The variety of rides offered at Dam Sen Water Park is commendable, providing a good mix of thrills and relaxation. The presence of adequate safety guards ensures a sense of security, allowing visitors to enjoy the attractions with peace of mind. While it might not be the largest water park, it offers a welcomed escape from the hustle and bustle of Ho Chi Minh City.

**Concerns at the Entrance Counter:** However, a major downside surfaced at the entrance counter, where phone covers and floats are sold. The exorbitant pricing of $20 for a phone cover, coupled with the staff's attempt to push unnecessary purchases by stating that each cover accommodates only one phone, appears exploitative, especially towards foreigners. This practice of trying to extract more money from visitors by enforcing unnecessary purchases significantly detracted from an otherwise enjoyable experience.

**Final Thoughts:** Despite the regrettable encounter at the entrance counter, Dam Sen Water Park remains a decent option for a day of relaxation and fun in Ho Chi Minh City. The park's cleanliness, well-maintained rides, and attentive staff contribute to an overall positive experience. However, potential visitors should be cautious and aware of possible tactics aimed at extracting additional money.

In summary, Dam Sen Water Park offers an enjoyable getaway from the city's hustle and bustle, featuring well-maintained rides and a clean environment. Nonetheless, the exploitative practices at the entrance counter regarding the sale of phone covers and floats merit attention and consideration before planning a visit.

placeMetadata.name: Mariamman Hindu temple

sources.shortName: attractions Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City Region

sources.snippet: Situated close to the Ben Thanh market, the Mariamman Hindu temple serves the small community of 100 or so Chinese and Vietnamese Tamil Hindus living in Ho Chi Minh City. It is the only Hindu temple that is still open in the city and is considered sacred by Hindu and non-Hindu Vietnamese. The temple is rumored to have miraculous powers, giving luck and wealth to those who worship within its walls.

sources.snippet: Mariamman Hindu Temple is a small slice of South Indian tradition located in Ho Chi Minh, dedicated to Hindu goddess Mariamman. The Mariamman Temple in Saigon (Ho Chi Minh City) offers a serene and sacred escape amidst the city's lively hustle and bustle. Nestled in the heart of District 1, this Hindu temple is dedicated to Mariamman, the goddess of rain and disease, and serves as a spiritual hub for both locals and visitors.

The temple’s vibrant and intricate architecture stands out with its colorful statues, detailed carvings, and ornate decorations. Upon entering, you’re greeted by the scent of incense and the sound of soft chants, which help create a peaceful ambiance that contrasts sharply with the surrounding urban activity. The temple's peaceful atmosphere invites you to pause and reflect, offering a sense of tranquility that feels almost otherworldly amid Saigon’s fast-paced energy.

Despite its relatively small size, the temple is a vital part of the local Hindu community, and visitors often come to pay their respects, pray for blessings, or seek protection from ailments. The temple also serves as a cultural touchstone for the Indian diaspora in Vietnam, preserving ancient rituals and traditions that have been passed down for generations.

What makes the Mariamman Temple especially unique is its location in one of the most dynamic areas of the city. Walking through the busy streets, where street vendors and motorcycles bustle by, then stepping into the quiet sanctuary of the temple creates a striking contrast and a reminder of the city’s rich cultural and spiritual diversity.

Overall, the Mariamman Temple is an exceptional spot for those interested in exploring the spiritual side of Saigon. Its divine presence amidst the chaos offers a unique experience of serenity and reflection, making it a hidden gem for both spiritual seekers and curious travelers alike.

Nestled in the vibrant heart of Ho Chi Minh City, the Mariamman Hindu Temple, fondly known as Chùa Bà Ấn Độ, stands as a captivating testament to cultural fusion at 45 Trương Định Street, District 1. Built in the early 20th century by Tamil merchants from South India, this sacred site began as a humble shrine to serve the spiritual needs of Indian immigrants in Saigon. Over time, it evolved into a magnificent structure, reconstructed between 1950-1952, showcasing intricate Hindu architecture with its iconic U-shaped layout, vibrant gopuram tower, and 18 divine statues symbolizing human aspirations. Dedicated to Goddess Mariamman, revered for blessings of prosperity, health, and fertility, the temple radiates spiritual allure.
The temple’s history intertwines with Saigon’s growth, reflecting the significant contributions of the Indian community. These merchants, primarily Chettiyars, enriched Saigon’s economy through trade and commerce, fostering cultural exchange that shaped the city’s diverse identity. The temple became a beacon of unity, welcoming not only Hindus but also Vietnamese and Chinese worshippers, blending Hindu rituals with local Buddhist practices. Daily fire ceremonies at 10 AM and 7 PM draw devotees seeking divine blessings, while its proximity to landmarks like Bến Thành Market enhances its role as a cultural hub.
Mariamman Temple is more than a place of worship; it’s a living legacy of India’s enduring influence on Saigon’s multicultural tapestry. Visiting this sacred space, with its serene ambiance and architectural splendor, inspires awe and appreciation for the harmonious blend of cultures that continues to define Ho Chi Minh City.
Beautiful temple in the middle of the hustle and bustle of Saigon. A glimpse of South India.

Thank you for your service 🇻🇳❤️😊🙏

Picture this: a late 19th-century temple built by Tamil traders, dedicated to the goddess Mariamman, who, let’s be honest, sounds like the superhero of deities—curing diseases & bringing rain. Move over, Marvel.

Architecturally, this place is like a colorful explosion of South Indian style. The gopuram (that’s fancy talk for the tower at the entrance) is adorned with enough statues and carvings to keep you staring in awe for days. And don’t even get me started on the inside—statues of Ganesha, Vishnu, and of course, Mariamman herself. It’s like a who’s who of the Hindu pantheon.

Here’s the kicker: this temple isn’t just for Hindus. You’ve got Buddhists, local Vietnamese, and more than a couple of confused tourists all flocking here to pray for health, prosperity, and protection from evil spirits. It’s a melting pot of faith, wrapped up in a vibrant, cultural hug.

So, if you find yourself in Saigon, do yourself a favor and swing by this temple. It’s a historical gem, a cultural blend, and a place where the past and present collide in the most colorful way possible. Plus, where else can you get a spiritual boost and a history lesson all in one go?

placeMetadata.name: Compass Offices - Bitexco Financial Tower - Serviced Office Ho Chi Minh City

sources.shortName: Must-see attractions Ho Chi Minh City Region, Vietnam

sources.snippet: When the 68-story, 262-meter (859-foot) high Bitexco Financial Tower was completed in 2010, it became the highest building in Vietnam. Today, its Sky Deck, which is located on the 49th floor, is a popular tourist attractions in Ho Chi Minh City where visitors can enjoy amazing 360-degree views of the city and of the Saigon River. The Bitexco Financial Tower has two restaurants on the 50th and 51st floor that also provide amazing views of the surrounding area.
sources.shortName: 10 Top Attractions in Ho Chi Minh City (+Map)

sources.snippet: Six of the Bitexco Financial Tower floors have been given over to retail space although the main draw here is not shopping, rather the views. The public observation deck on the 49th floor is reached by using one of the tower’s 16 elevators which can reach any floor regardless of level within 35 seconds. The tower is also well-known for its Bitexco Vertical Run where competitors race from the ground floor lobby to the Sky Deck.

placeMetadata.name: Turtle Lake

sources.snippet: The Turtle Lake is a traffic circle with a small lake in the center, surrounded by a landscaped park and pedestrian walkways. It is situated at the intersection of Pham Ngoc Thach, Vo Van Tan, and Tran Cao Van Streets in District 3. The lake gets its name from the large stone sculpture of a turtle positioned in the center of the water, which has become a symbol of the area.

Picture this: a quirky roundabout with a turtle fountain that’s practically a local landmark. It’s like someone thought, “Hey, let’s put a giant turtle in the middle of a lake and see what happens!” And it worked brilliantly.

By day, it’s a peaceful spot where you can catch your breath. By night, it turns into a street food haven, with vendors serving up everything from fried squid to corn on the cob.

Whether you’re there for the oddball charm or just to grab a bite and chill, this place has got you covered. It’s a bit of quirky bliss in the middle of Saigon!
It was super cool! It was beautiful at golden hour, and a ton of people were having full on photo shoots in the area. We also loved all the flowers around the area. It was cool to explore

Good place but doesn’t have same good attention. Looks abandon

But love atmosphere here with this gigantic trees which cover you with their crones from a burning sun. And this green pool with trace and paths above like a turtle back.

come here for dinner.
after 7pm.
too early and the food vendors would not have set up their stalls.

most of the stalls sell similar food.
so just pick a nice spot and order from the vendor in front of you

more a place to chill rather than see anything

reviews.reviewText: Great experience and definitely a place to remember. Didn’t expect it to be a base camp for the Vietnamese during the war, so that was an awesome bonus as well. Make sure to not have anything out or take photos quickly and carefully😁
Nice and interesting place to visit in Can Gio island!

the mangrove forest is beautiful. walking through the forest is also very easy as the terrain was mostly flat.

monkeys were chill during my visit - it was so nice to see them swinging and walking around. they seem to have easy access to trash though so they scatter litter when they scavenge for food. hopefully trash can be secured better.

If you can ask for the guards to take you in to feed them. It’s a fun experience because they know the monkeys and which ones are mean. They also protect you from the monkeys stealing your stuff.
Super fun :)

We visited this place on a weekday. Good for a walk in nature. The museum is nice, with a lot of history, only one location to see monkeys. The fee for foreigners is higher than locals, 3 times more, I don't know why... The ride in the boat is also expensive. We walked around for 2 hours, but a lot of trash and no maintenance in the place. Also, some monkeys seem sick. I think they don't care about the place just about the money. It is around 2 hours from Hcmc.

This place is pretty much fine, yes the "guards" don't really protect anyone, although the one they should protect would be the animals, you can finely walk through the route without attracting the monkeys with your food, or anything else you keep in your hand, just keep it in your bag and closed have a sip of water when there are less or none around, they also steal glasses quite often, i understand if u have dioptric lenses that u might not be able to see anything, so if you decide to keep them on don't let the monkeys get to the point where they are able to snap them away, learn to evade, but please don't attack the monkeys, fr can't you even not eat food within 1-2 hour walk through a forest, how dumb you are, it is even written on the board to not bring any food with you, the monkeys do follow you, but in my case, as long as i don't attract their attention unnecessarily they won't do nothing, i saw some visitors carrying a stick to beat the monkeys, such people should be heavily fined, behave yourself, you're in foreign environment, a one that we stole and have deprived of resources, so have some respect or don't even bother to visit, most of the negative reviews are of those below the monkey's iq, just spoilt kids in adult body, you can bring the monkeys some natural food, they do fight each other if you displace it irresponsibly, but they're monkeys not university students.

This was a memorable place to visit while in Vietnam. The monkeys are everywhere (except the crocodile pen). The monkeys here reeeeeaaaallly like ice cream. If you walk anywhere with some, they’re going to snatch it. Rumor has it that ice cream can be traded to get back your sunglasses (which they love), hats (which they love), phones (which they love), or any other physical object (which YOU love). Leave as much as you can in the car, bus, or people movers. Rangers can often get stuff back for you, but sometimes they’re just not there when it happens.

Some tour guides liked to carry sticks to fend off the monkeys, but aided by our tour guide, we were wisely told that if a monkey does approach you or jump on you, try not to freak out. They are most interested in what they can steal off of you (don’t have it on you in the first place) and they just want to smell you and see what you’re all about.

Good for people who want to explore local history and nature. About 1 hour by driving from Ho Chi Minh city.

The weather is extremely hot, thus recommend to using electric car to commute from main gate to visiting area (about 1km). You van buy tickets at the gate (reservation is not necessary). You should bring a lot a water and personal fan. Be careful with your snack and belongings since the monkeys there is quite aggressive.

placeMetadata.name: Pham Ngu Lao

sources.snippet: Sort of like Bangkok’s Khao San road, the area of Pham Ngu Lao, and also Bui Vien Street, is the most famous budget backpacker district of Ho Chi Minh City. There are dozens of hotels, guest houses, and hostels along these two streets, ranging from very budget to mid-range, and I even noticed a few (sort of out of place) higher end hotels on Bui Vien Street as well. Since this area is dominated by foreign backpackers and travelers, Pham Ngu Lao is also a big party nightlife area, and among the hostels are numerous bars, nightclubs, and massage parlors.
sources.shortName: 23 Things To Do In Saigon (Ho Chi Minh City): Top Attractions!

sources.snippet: Highlights: Pham Ngu Lao Street is a place that appeals to backpackers. There are various grades of hotels and budget hotels all over the street, roadside shops, travel agency agents, foreign currency exchange points, restaurants of various flavors, western restaurants, bars, coffee houses and local specialties. Commodity stores are row upon row.
sources.shortName: Top 18 Best Things to Do in Ho Chi Minh City

sources.snippet: Located in District 1, Pham Ngu Lao Street is often dubbed the ‘backpacker district’ of Ho Chi Minh City. It’s a vibrant stretch bustling with life – street vendors, bars, cafes, and affordable accommodations. By day, tourists can find an array of affordable souvenirs, local foods, and intricate handicrafts.
sources.siteName: The Planet D: Adventure Travel Blog
sources.shortName: 32 Best Things to Do in Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam

placeMetadata.description: Buzzing Pham Ngu Lao is centered on backpacker hotspot Bùi Viện street, where homestyle Vietnamese eateries sit next to tiny shops offering souvenirs, clothing, and tattoos. A raucous nightlife scene includes sidewalk beer cafes and back-alley dive bars, plus cocktail spots and dance clubs. The leafy September 23rd Park has a playground and duck pond, while elegant Huyện Sĩ Church is known for its soaring tower.

sources.snippet: Dong Khoi street and area of Saigon, sort of reminds me of Oxford Street, it’s an upscale area of Saigon, and along Dong Khoi street you’ll find high end boutiques and designer stores. sources.shortName: 23 Things To Do In Saigon (Ho Chi Minh City): Top Attractions!

sources.snippet: For those searching out the best shopping and dining experiences in Saigon, Dong Khoi Street is the place to go. This street is home to elegant old colonial buildings, high-end boutiques, famous brand-name stores, lovely cafes and restaurants and luxury hotels. Some of the more well-known buildings on this street are the Opera House, the Saigon Central Post Office, and the Notre Dame Cathedral.

Bùi Viện Walking Street in Ho Chi Minh City is definitely a lively and bustling spot, especially if you're into vibrant nightlife. For the more adventurous, there’s a mix of music, street performances, and a variety of activities happening at all hours. However, if you’re not fond of crowds or noise, this may not be the spot for you. Overall, it’s a fun and energetic atmosphere, particularly for those in their 20s or 30s.

placeMetadata.description: Sprawling Buddhist temple with traditional architecture, a 25m-tall tower & a vegetarian restaurant.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Vinh Nghiem Buddhist Temple, located in Ho Chi Minh City, is a sprawling complex that showcases traditional Vietnamese architecture with a modern Japanese-inspired touch. The temple features a 25-meter-tall tower and a vegetarian restaurant for visitors to enjoy. It is known for its unique design, incorporating elements from Khmer, Vietnamese, and Cham styles. The main building houses precious documents and Buddhist artworks, while the walls and roofs are adorned with thousands of ceramic plates.

A real hidden gem for your next cultural adventure.

This place isn’t just about gorgeous architecture & a massive Buddha statue; it’s also a visual feast. The illustrations on the Law of Karma are like the comic strips of spiritual wisdom—vivid, engaging, and totally worth a closer look. It’s like someone said, “Hey, let’s make the concept of karma as fun as possible!”

Whether you’re into deep thoughts or just want to snap some rad pics, this temple has it all. So, if you’re ready for some serious Zen and a dose of karma with a side of fabulous artwork, this is your spot.

placeMetadata.name: Ao Dai Museum

sources.snippet: The Aao Dai Museum is a fascinating museum located in Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam. Dedicated to the traditional Vietnamese garment known as the "Ao Dai," this museum showcases the history, significance, and evolution of this iconic attire. The Ao Dai is a long, figure-hugging dress that is considered the national costume of Vietnam and is worn by both men and women on special occasions.
sources.shortName: 21 Places to Visit in Ho Chi Minh City in 2024

sources.snippet: Located at a distance from the city centre in District 9, Ao Dai museum celebrates the national dress of Vietnam in a picturesque landscape. Surrounded by coconut trees and canals, the museum traces the evolution of the Ao Dai through the years. On display are several beautiful pieces owned by royals and celebrities, and you can even try one on and get a photo clicked.
sources.shortName: 52 Best Things To Do in Ho Chi Minh City Vietnam 2025

sources.snippet: Heading to District 9 (a 1-hour drive via local public bus from District 1), visit the enthralling Ao Dai Museum.

A true hidden gem, the Áo Dài Museum offers a peaceful and visually stunning experience, perfect for photography. Unlike the overcrowded attractions in Ho Chi Minh City, this museum remains largely undiscovered, with weekdays often so quiet that visitors may have the grounds entirely to themselves—a luxury that surely won’t last as word spreads.

The collection of áo dài is impressive, showcasing everything from historical designs to modern interpretations, each reflecting Vietnam’s rich cultural heritage. Most signs are in both Vietnamese and English, guiding visitors through the evolution of this iconic garment. The museum’s architecture, with its wooden corridors and open spaces, blends seamlessly with the lush, well-maintained landscape. The tranquil pond, complete with lotus flowers and fish from the very grounds, adds to the authenticity and charm of the setting.

For those seeking a cultural experience away from the crowds, this is an exceptional destination. The combination of history, fashion, and stunning scenery makes it a must-visit before it inevitably gains the attention it deserves.

Ticket with 50k per pax, the environment is good and greenery, however the exhibition hall doesn’t have Aircond. The weather is hot and must prepare your cooler stuff. Museum place is big but not as expected.

placeMetadata.name: Giang Dien waterfall

sources.snippet: If you love waterfalls, Giang Dien Waterfall is the right place for you to visit on a day trip from Saigon. Giang Dien Waterfall in Dong Nai province is now considered as the new eco-tourism area and attracts a lot of tourists from Ho Chi Minh City and neighboring provinces. Giang Dien Waterfall may not be as spectacular as the falls in the Central Highlands, but you will still feel really impressed by the beautiful scenery with lots of wild flowers and butterflies, and lust green trees.
sources.shortName: Best Places for Day Trip from Ho Chi Minh City

While it may not rival the grandeur of waterfalls in the Central Highlands, its picturesque landscape with wildflowers, butterflies, and lush greenery is truly impressive. It's advisable to avoid visiting during holidays or the wet season due to traffic congestion and muddy rivers; however, the serene spots near the waterfall are always refreshing.

placeMetadata.name: Landmark 81

sources.snippet: Landmark 81 Vietnam, towering at a height of 461 meters, holds the distinction of being Vietnam's tallest building and the 14th tallest globally. Step into the high-speed elevator and watch the cityscape transform beneath your feet as you ascend to incredible heights. Once you reach the observation deck, a breathtaking vista unfolds before you, revealing the vibrant tapestry of Ho Chi Minh City.
sources.shortName: 15 Unmissable Places to Visit in Ho Chi Minh City

sources.snippet: The next Saigon tourist destination that Lily’s Travel wants to introduce is Landmark 81. Vincom Landmark 81 is not only the tallest building in Saigon but also the tallest building in Southeast Asia, the pride of the Vietnamese people. And, of course, if you look at the panoramic view of Saigon from such a high place, there is nothing like it.
sources.shortName: Ho Chi Minh Tourist attractions: 2 places you have to visit, and 3 ways to help you explore all attractions

sources.snippet: Standing at 461 meters tall, Landmark 81 Vietnam is the tallest building in Vietnam and the 14th tallest in the world. It is located in the Vinhomes Central Park development in Binh Thanh district and offers stunning panoramic views of the city. The observation deck is located on the 79th floor and is accessible via a high-speed elevator.
sources.shortName: Places to visit in Ho Chi Minh City: Top popular attractions

reviews.reviewText: Landmark 81 was an amazing experience! We went all the way to the top, and the view was absolutely stunning—definitely worth it. The whole area around the tower is also really nice to explore. The parks are beautifully maintained, offering a relaxing spot to walk around or just enjoy the scenery. We spent the afternoon and evening there, and it was such a great way to unwind and take in the city. Highly recommend visiting if you’re in town!

If you are looking for a place to stay in Ho Chi Minh City, I think this place is very good. There is a wide variety of food, both Vietnamese and Korean. On the ground floor, there is a park with a great atmosphere. At night, the wind blows very cool, suitable for chilling out with friends and talking. I walked around and found a shopping mall near the condo where I was staying. The view is very beautiful. From my room, I could see the lake. The staff provided excellent service. However, it was quite difficult to contact the owner of the room I rented. I arrived at the airport and when I was about to arrive at the accommodation, he still hadn't called to ask where I was going to leave my stuff or what time I could check in. Plus, the cleaning was slow and difficult to contact. He said that check-in was at 2 pm. I went for a walk until 2:30 pm and he still hadn't contacted me back. Plus, during the four days I stayed, there was no cleaning at all. The soaps in the bathroom were not refilled for new guests, and the packaging was broken. It was very bad.

Vinpearl Landmark 81, Autograph Collection, is a luxurious hotel situated within Vietnam's tallest building in Ho Chi Minh City. Occupying floors 47 to 71, the hotel offers guests breathtaking panoramic views of the city. The property features an infinity pool on the 47th floor, providing a unique vantage point for relaxation.

The hotel is incredibly beautiful and the staff are very attentive.From the front lobby with its grand tall ceilings and modern marble/gold finishes, you feel like royalty.

The hotel's location in the Bình Thạnh district provides easy access to a shopping mall, ice skating rink, cinema, and various dining options, making it a convenient choice for travelers seeking both comfort and entertainment.

Overall, Vinpearl Landmark 81, Autograph Collection, offers a memorable and luxurious stay, combining exceptional service, stunning views, and a prime location in Ho Chi Minh City.

The building is tall and impressive, with a shopping mall, cinema, high-end restaurants, and an observation deck.
From the top, you get a panoramic view of the city — especially beautiful at sunset.
However, ticket prices and dining here can be quite expensive compared to local standards.
A great spot for visitors who want to experience a luxury atmosphere and enjoy the skyline from above.

Pretty cool experience to see the city from such height. They have different types of ticket, only recommend the standard. It was around 300,000 vnd per person in Mar 2025. Although it's all glasses but you can't see anything underneath your feet as there is another level right under you.

Must visit if you're into citylights and heights. Saigon looked magnificent from the 81st floor ✨
The whole experience is very well curated and there is absolutely no confusion getting around and having a grand time.

My personal favourite was the VR skydiving game. It was very thrilling 🔥

It is a really nice place, we had an amazing room and view. Also had good food. 2 things though, the curtains didn’t close correctly in the corners and almost every control was on a little screen type. But they were really good and nice people, especially Mr. Hank. We had a problem with the air conditioning and it took 3 hours to fix. 5 people were in the room so we could not relax and pack our bags. Also, they lost some of our laundry. Took away the most important thing in a family, time. We had to waste more than five hours on all this crap. on the first day, they told us the hotel is about 60% full when we have this issue with the air conditioning, we asked if we could just move to another connecting room because I was with my parents, they said they have none left. What type of five star hotel treats 2  ambassadors (my parents) like that?

We bought the package with take out drink and VR for $480k/adult. VR only lasted 5 minutes so not worth it and the drink was a small cup of juices or coffee /tea so I don't recommend getting the package. If it rains they won't let you go up to the glass walk way to take pictures which is the highlight for landmark 81 for the 180 degree views.

placeMetadata.name: Heritage Chinatown

sources.snippet: Step into the vibrant heart of Ho Chi Minh City's Cho Lon, and you'll find yourself enveloped in a world where the past and present merge to create an experience that's as rich in history as it is in sensory delights. Known as the city's Chinatown, Cho Lon is a tapestry of cultural heritage, bustling markets, and culinary adventures that await your discovery.
sources.shortName: Top Things To Do & Must-See Attractions

sources.snippet: Explore bustling markets, centuries-old temples, alleys brimming with historic architecture, and delicious street food, all combined in one place to create an immersive cultural experience.

The district is known for its abundance of shops offering affordable Christmas decorations, making it a popular shopping destination. However, Heritage Chinatown offers more than just shopping opportunities. Visitors can explore Tan Dinh for textiles, purchase an array of spices in the neighborhood, or experience the vibrant street market at Vo Duy Ninh in Binh Thanh.

This place located in China Town District 5 and it is exactly Chinese style. I visited there right after Tet 2025 but this place looked dirty and dusty, 2 kumquat trees were very dry and the leaves were getting yellow although many people were sit near it but not take care of them.

It’s in same yard with the high school, I don’t know how visitors can concentrate on praying because it’s quite noisy..

I love it
