placeMetadata.name: Saigon Skydeck

sources.snippet: Not too far from the Ben Thanh Market you can find the Bitexco Financial Tower, where the amazing Saigon Skydeck is located. It is on the 49th floor and has a great 360-degrees view at Ho Chi Minh City. We totally love viewpoints and if you do so too, don’t miss that one.
sources.siteName: Travel Blog: Home is where your Bag is - Holiday Tips & City Trips
sources.shortName: 20 Things to Do in Ho Chi Minh City (Saigon)

sources.snippet: Located on the 49th floor is the tower’s observation station, the Saigon Skydeck, offering visitors unparalleled 360-degree views of Ho Chi Minh City below.
sources.shortName: 60 Fun & Unusual Things to Do in Ho Chi Minh City

placeMetadata.description: Glass-enclosed observation deck on the 49th floor of the Bitexco Financial Tower with scenic views.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Nestled on the 49th floor of the iconic Bitexco Financial Tower, Saigon Skydeck offers an unforgettable experience for those seeking breathtaking views of Ho Chi Minh City. Standing at a remarkable height of 178 meters, this glass-enclosed observation deck provides a stunning panoramic vista that captures both the vibrant cityscape and the serene curves of the Saigon River. Visitors can take advantage of six high-tech telescopes that allow for an immersive exploration of distant landmarks from various angles.
placeMetadata.address: 36 Hồ Tùng Mậu, Bến Nghé, Quận 1, Hồ Chí Minh, Vietnam

reviews.reviewText: Certainly worth seeing if you're in the area. I bought my ticket online and with the "I'm old" discount paid about $6.50 US. I went late morning on a weekday and there was no line. I was on the hi-speed elevator in less than 1 minute for a quick ride to the observation deck which is just below the platform of the building. It was only a bit hazy on a Feb day and the view was excellent. There were only a few dozen people which was nice. Besides the view, there is a tiny museum of traditional woman's clothing and a few beautiful tiny bamboo buildings. There's also a gift shop where you can get a free bottle of water (warm) and buy some overpriced souvenirs. I got some good pix and was ready to go after 20 minutes or so.

The Saigon Skydeck, located on the 49th floor of the Bitexco Financial Tower in Ho Chi Minh City, offers breathtaking 360-degree panoramic views of the city. The observatory is a must-visit for anyone looking to experience the vibrant skyline of Saigon, especially during clear days or just before sunset. The glass windows provide an unobstructed view, making it a perfect spot for photography enthusiasts.

Visitors can enjoy additional features such as the Ao Dai exhibition, interactive information panels about the tower, and large screens that highlight key landmarks in the city. The Skydeck also has a souvenir shop for those looking to take home memorabilia. The experience is enhanced by the modern amenities, including air conditioning and binoculars for a closer look at distant attractions.

The ticket prices are reasonable, with discounts available for children, seniors, and disabled individuals. The Skydeck is open daily from 9:30 AM to 9:30 PM, allowing ample time to explore and soak in the views. Whether you're a local or a tourist, the Saigon Skydeck is a fantastic way to appreciate the beauty of Ho Chi Minh City from above.

I had an amazing experience at Saigon Skydeck! The ticket prices were very affordable, and the 360° views of the city were absolutely stunning. The staff were kind and welcoming, and we also received complimentary water with our tickets.

I loved the cultural displays—there was an engaging section about the traditional Vietnamese dress the ao dai and how it has evolved over time. Another highlight was the interactive bamboo structure—visitors could add their own small bamboo sticks to a growing installation, which was such a creative and meaningful experience to be a part of.

Overall, it was a great mix of breathtaking views and rich cultural insight. Highly recommend!

No line, no wait~ just pay and walked straight into Saigon Skydeck around 9PM and it did not disappoint. The night view was absolutely unreal. The entire city lit up beneath you, and the binoculars let you zoom in on Saigon’s wild traffic from above. It’s mesmerizing.

The mini gallery of traditional Vietnamese costumes was a nice cultural touch that gave the experience more depth. A perfect blend of modern cityscape and local heritage.

This is a must. Great way to take in the city from a whole new angle.

Enjoyed my visit, although I thought the observation deck was the part that protrudes from the building, but when you are purchasing your ticket they will tell you that it’s not, that it’s the helicopter pad. I like to be outside on observation desks, it adds to the experience, but this was nice, too! I went there at sunset, so got to see the city during daylight and after dark.

placeMetadata.name: Ho Chi Minh City Book Street

sources.snippet: Located near Notre Dame Cathedral and the Central Post Office in District 1, Nguyen Van Binh Book Street is the must-visit destination for book lovers. I love the feeling of wandering around, buying some books, and reading them at the coffee shops on a Sunday morning. Nguyen Van Binh book street is the first book complex in Vietnam built with open space, allowing visitors to visit and enjoy the reading culture of the Saigon.
sources.shortName: 10+ Best Places To Visit In Ho Chi Minh Vietnam

sources.snippet: Saigon Book Street or Nguyen Van Binh Book Street is over 100 meters long between Hai Ba Trung Street and Notre Dame Cathedral in the heart of District 1 so it is often crowded during the day and night. Saigon Book Street was opened with the desire to improve the reading culture of young people in the city. There are more than 20 different bookstores and publisher shops with unique décor.
sources.shortName: Top Attractions in Saigon (Ho Chi Minh City) that you do not want to miss (Part 1) - La Siesta Premium Saigon

placeMetadata.description: Buzzy, pedestrian-only street with Vietnamese & expat bookstores, plus spots for al fresco coffee.
placeMetadata.address: Đ. Nguyễn Văn Bình, Bến Nghé, Quận 1, Hồ Chí Minh, Vietnam

reviews.reviewText:
A fantastic little place right in the heart of the city, Ho Chi Minh City Book Street is an absolute must for book lovers and café seekers alike. Just around the corner from the iconic Central Post Office, this peaceful tree-lined street offers a unique escape from the city’s buzz.

Lined with bookshops, from local publishers to stalls with international selections, there’s something for readers of all kinds—whether you’re into romance, thrillers, or thought-provoking non-fiction. Many shops also offer stationery, postcards, and souvenirs, giving it a charming blend of local culture and creativity.

There are several shaded benches and casual cafés where you can sip on a Vietnamese coffee or tea while diving into your latest read. The atmosphere is relaxed and welcoming, and you could easily spend an hour or two browsing, sitting back, or people-watching.

Art installations and sculptures add to the charm, and the entire space feels thoughtfully curated and community-focused. It’s clean, pedestrian-only, and a great place to slow down.

I highly recommend it for solo travelers, couples, or anyone looking for a break in a calm and creative setting. A refreshing change of pace right in the middle of District 1.

Overhyped. It’s a nice short street, only worth going because it’s directly next to the post office. Might have some nice postcards, but that’s about it. There’s a normal looking cafe (not insta worthy) , some street artist doing caricature. But really, that’s about it. Maybe i had too high expectations. The books are all in Vietnamese. The street is a nice photo point overlooking the Notre Dame. Since there’s nothing much to do in Saigon, you could put this in your itinerary. Sorry for the honest review.

A lovely and well-developed book street—clean, charming, and full of character. Besides books, you can find unique, personalized souvenirs too. The atmosphere is great for a relaxed stroll. I’d recommend visiting around 5 PM for fewer crowds and better photo opportunities. Definitely worth a stop!

Absolutely blown away with this book street. I visited during public holiday and it was pleasantly crowded. There were so many bookshops and all of them were amazing. Some shops had really wide selection of books even in English. I got myself postcards, notebook, and bookmarks with good prices and again, all of them were pretty that you’d regret for not getting. If I visit HCMC again, I’ll definitely go back here again.

Book Street isn’t as vibrant as it used to be, but it’s still lively and has a steady crowd. It was never really a quiet spot, but walking around is still a nice experience. There’s not much that stands out now, but it’s still worth a quick visit since it’s close to other tourist landmarks in the area.

Such a cute and charming street! Book Street is located right next to the Saigon Central Post Office and the Notre-Dame Cathedral, so it’s super easy to find if you’re visiting those landmarks.

I came on a weekday early in the morning, and it was so peaceful—not crowded at all, which made it even more enjoyable. You can just stroll, take your time, and explore the cozy bookshops, little cafés, and seating areas.

Definitely worth a visit if you’re a book lover or just looking for a quiet spot in the city!

Such a lovely book street. Definitely a haven for book lovers. You will defintely enjoy looking around. Some stores  sells souvenir stuffs. Some stores also has stationery stuffs. I even got a Jujutsu Kaisen stickers from here.  Great place to buy gifts for loved ones too. We also saw a cafe here . Definitely a must visit for book lovers.

Wide selection of postcard and book stores. Has a few cafe inside. For cheaper post cards, theres a shop at the farthest corner or you can buy from street vendors outside just a few feet from the book street itself. A nice street to just aimlessly wander around.

sources.snippet: Quan Am Pagoda is a beautiful 19th-century Buddhist temple dedicated to Quan Am, the Goddess of Mercy and Compassion. Situated in Cholon in District 5, the temple complex is divided into three areas, with altars dedicated to Sea Goddess Mazu, the Jade Emperor and Quan Am. A courtyard with a small pond leads into the temple, where colourful motifs and sculptures welcome visitors.
sources.shortName: 52 Best Things To Do in Ho Chi Minh City Vietnam 2025

placeMetadata.description: Pagoda devoted to the Buddhist bodhisattva Quan Âm, featuring courtyards, a garden & a pond.

The pagoda features courtyards, a garden, and a pond. Its architecture includes colorful 'glove-puppet' figurines on the roofs and teetering houses that create an illusion of a gingerbread house from a distance.
placeMetadata.address: 12 Đ. Lão Tử, Phường 11, Quận 5, Hồ Chí Minh, Vietnam

reviews.reviewerName: Follow Me On X / Twitter - triplexgnet
reviews.reviewText:
Pros:
1. Peaceful and serene place to worship.
2. Convenient location to travel either using your own car or motorbike or by travelling with transportation services (e.g. Grab, Be, Xanh SM).
3. Helpful street vendors.
4. Open and airy space.

Cons:
1. Visitors should respect the serenity of this place by avoiding taking photos and videos and putting silent their mobile phones.
2. Foreigner travellers should behave properly when visiting this place by following and respecting dress codes when visiting temples or pagodas.

Quan Am Temple is a Chinese-style Buddhist temple located on Lao Tu Street in Cho Lon, District 5, Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam. Founded in the 19th century, it is dedicated to Guanyin, the Chinese goddess of mercy and the Chinese form of the Indian bodhisattva Avalokiteshvara. Tara is a female Buddha and goddess in Buddhism who is considered a saviour and a source of enlightenment. She is also known as the "Mother of all Buddhas" and the "Wisdom Goddess".
Appearance
Tara is often depicted seated on a lotus throne
She is sometimes depicted with a white or green color scheme
She is sometimes depicted with skulls, which symbolize mortality
Origin
According to Tibetan mythology, Tara originated from tears shed by the Buddhist god Avalokiteshvara
In popular belief, a tear from Avalokiteshvara fell to the ground, forming a lake, and a lotus rose from the water, revealing Tara
Significance
Tara is a compassionate deity who helps people "cross to the other shore"
She is the protectress of navigation, earthly travel, and spiritual travel
She is believed to be a source of the female aspect of the universe
She is especially revered in Vajrayana Buddhism and Mahayana Buddhism

A very beautiful and colorful temple hidden in a small street. There are many interesting traditions there I want to experience. On the opposite side of the temple, there was a small pond with fish. I was there on a normal weekday at quite an early hour in the morning so the temple was not crowded. Outside, there were many street vendors that people could buy stuff to bring into the temple to offer and pray.

Alright, let's set the scene: me, an atheist, standing in this serene pagoda. Now, you might think, "What’s an atheist doing at a place of worship?" Well, it turns out, watching people practice their faith is oddly fascinating!

This place is a sanctuary of calm in the bustling city, with the scent of incense in the air and a gentle hum of prayers around you. The architecture? Stunning. The carvings? Intricate and beautiful. And the people? Full of devotion, lighting incense and making offerings with a kind of grace and sincerity that’s both humbling & uplifting.

So, if you're in Ho Chi Minh City, whether you're a believer or not, this pagoda is worth a visit. It's like stepping into a different world where you can observe, reflect, and just take a moment to appreciate the diversity of human expression.
It’s big, smoky, and packed with statues, and the heavy scent of incense. Amazing atmosphere with gold aesthetic. Right in the middle of city

Beautiful place especially the Koi pond.

Lots of pple praying and visiting.

Near Ba Thien Hou Temple too

Such an interesting and atmospheric place, it is with a visit for 10/15 minutes to soak in the culture and atmosphere. The sights and smell of burning incense is amazing and very unique to this place.

Beautiful preservation of culture and a lovely escape within the busy city life for anyone visiting the city.
This was an interesting temple as there were many dieties throughout. There were lots of things going on with locals and priests praying.

placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Phước An Hội Quán, a Taoist temple dating back to 1902, is a stunningly ornate and colorful place of worship located in Ho Chi Minh City's Cholon or Chinatown area. The temple boasts elaborate wood carvings, brass ritual ornaments, vibrant lanterns, and intricate spiral incense coils hanging from the ceiling. Visitors can admire the detailed designs on the walls and explore the ceramic scenes decorating the roof.
placeMetadata.address: 184 Đ. Hồng Bàng, Phường 12, Quận 5, Hồ Chí Minh, Vietnam

reviews.reviewText:
Imagine walking into a place where Chinese architecture meets Islamic artistry- all set against the vibrant backdrop of Cholon. It's like if a kung fu movie set and a desert oasis had a baby, and that baby grew up to be a cultural gem in the heart of Ho Chi Minh City.

The first thing that strikes you is the blend of styles: intricate Chinese woodwork meets Islamic calligraphy, with a splash of green that feels refreshingly cool amidst the hustle and bustle of the city. It's a peaceful retreat where you can hear yourself think—if you're not too busy admiring the beautiful pond and lush courtyard.

Whether you're a history buff, a culture vulture, or just someone looking for a quiet place to escape the city noise, this temple is a must-visit. It’s not just a religious site; it's a testament to the diverse tapestry that makes up Saigon.

So, if you're in town, pop in and soak up some tranquility and history. You might just find yourself feeling a bit more Zen!
If you intend to visit, please know that as of December 2024 the Google directions send you to the rear of the building. The entrance is on the busy street side, not the back. I hope this helps.
What a beautiful place. A bit less visited than the other nearby temples. Very ornate details and thick with heavy incense.

Nice place to take a memorable pics.
You can look around free of charge

Very peaceful temple.
Not very big.

Although there are no strict rules, but makes sure you wear clothing that covers your shoulders and knees as respect to the locals and the temple.
A Chinese Buddhist temple. Can feel the atmosphere of Lunar New year here. It's one of the relics of Vietnam. A good place to go if you're tourist
A Chinese temple. A place to go
They close the temple whenever they like… or the times on here are highly inaccurate and waste people’s time .. which is sad

placeMetadata.name: Xa Loi Buddhist Temple

sources.snippet: Gracing the intersection of Ð Dong Khoi and ÐL Le Loi, this grand colonial edifice with a sweeping staircase was built in 1897 and is one of the city's…
sources.shortName: Must-see attractions Ho Chi Minh City Region, Vietnam

sources.snippet: The biggest pagoda in Ho Chi Minh, Xa Loi Pagoda is as famous for it dramatic history as it is for its beautiful statues, towers and intricately carved panels. Once the centre of Buddhism, the complex was home to renowned Buddhist monk Thich Quang Duc. It was raided by Army officials in 1963 for being a site of dissent against the Roman Catholic president Ngo Dinh Diem.
sources.shortName: 52 Best Things To Do in Ho Chi Minh City Vietnam 2025

placeMetadata.description: This tall, prominent Buddhist pagoda built in 1956 was raided by government forces in 1963.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Xa Loi Buddhist Temple, also known as Giac Lam Pagoda, is a prominent and historic Buddhist pagoda located in Ho Chi Minh City. Built in 1956, it features unique architecture with a seven-story stupa in Khmer, Vietnamese, and Cham styles. The main building houses precious documents, cultural artifacts, and Buddhist artworks.
placeMetadata.address: 89 Bà Huyện Thanh Quan, Phường Võ Thị Sáu, Quận 3, Hồ Chí Minh 70000, Vietnam

reviews.reviewText: Beautiful and serene. I love how colorful this place is and the bonsai trees are very well taken care of. Worth the visit!

Beautifully peaceful temple with gardens and many statues and monuments. A towering pagoda looks over the grounds and completes the Buddhist architecture wonderfully. The temple was built in 1958, and was the centre of Buddhist activism in the early 1960s. Home to Thich Quang Duc, the heroic monk that gave his life in protest of the persecution of Bhuddists by the Sth Vietnamese government. His monument is nearby the temple, and a visit to both is absolutely essential.
We had opportunity to visit this place before leaving Ho Chi Minh City just only 2 hours ago. I don’t hesitate to give you more information about this nice place for traveling.
Worth a visit as the way there is also quite interesting. It's quite a small compound and was not busy. It's scenic and tranquil.
It is the first pagoda i have visited in Saigon and i found this very interesting and calming this place is best to meditation and the statues are very so beautiful. One of the must visit in Saigon

Nice temple, big Buddha upstairs and cute bonsai garden in front of it.
There isn't much to visit but it's peaceful, local, and the Buddha is very nice.

placeMetadata.name: Bình Quới Tourist Village

sources.snippet: Bin Quoi is a tourist village and a popular destination for families. Reminiscent of the Mekong Delta, it consists of green lawns, walking paths, fishing ponds, open-air cottages, floating restaurants, and bamboo bridges. Traditional music and dance entertainment shows are held in the evening.
sources.shortName: 52 Best Things To Do in Ho Chi Minh City Vietnam 2025

sources.snippet: Tourists may find numerous thatched cottages in the northern countryside, sitting by the riversides enjoying fresh coconut under the shade of coconut trees.
sources.shortName: Ho Chi Minh City Tourist Attractions

placeMetadata.description: Set by the Saigon River, Bình Quới Tourist Village encompasses grassy lawns, tree-shaded walking paths, and indoor/outdoor fishing ponds. Land-based restaurants offer seating in open-air thatched cottages, while a huge floating restaurant has set menus and buffets. Bamboo bridges overlook giant lily pads and water wheels in tranquil lakes. Shows featuring traditional music and dance entertain visitors in the evening.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Bình Quới Tourist Village, located along the Saigon River, offers a serene escape with its lush lawns, shaded pathways, and fishing ponds. Visitors can dine in open-air thatched cottages or on a floating restaurant with set menus and buffets. Bamboo bridges overlook tranquil lakes adorned with giant lily pads and water wheels. In the evening, traditional music and dance shows entertain guests.

placeMetadata.name: Vinh Khanh Food Street

sources.snippet: For culinary enthusiasts, Vinh Khanh Street in District 4 is a gastronomic treasure trove for Vietnamese cuisine. As evening descends, the street comes alive with countless food stalls serving mouthwatering Vietnamese delicacies. From the famous ‘banh mi’ sandwiches, and sizzling seafood, to the iconic ‘pho,’ the array of flavors on offer is staggering.
sources.siteName: The Planet D: Adventure Travel Blog
sources.shortName: 32 Best Things to Do in Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam

sources.snippet: This is one of my favorite things to do in Ho Chi Minh City. Oc or snails are a popular delicacy in Vietnam and Vinh Khanh Street may be the best place to have them. Nicknamed “Seafood Street”, Vinh Khanh Street is a strip in District 4 with street food stalls on either side selling all kinds of fresh seafood.
sources.shortName: 20 Essential Things to Do in Ho Chi Minh City

placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Vinh Khanh Food Street is a bustling hub of street food in Ho Chi Minh City, lined with restaurants and outdoor grills where you can experience the joyful conviviality of Vietnamese cuisine. The specialty here is snails, prepared in various ways such as in coconut milk, with local vegetables, or covered in chili.
placeMetadata.address: 40 Đ. Vĩnh Khánh, Phường 8, Quận 4, Hồ Chí Minh, Vietnam

reviews.reviewText: This street has a lot of restaurants for drinking and eating street foods. Crowded in the weekend. Good place for friends and family to gather and have some fun

The street is full of seafood restaurants, they are all kinda the same and provide the same dishes. I feel safer to eat seafood here than in other tourist streets in Saigon because at least this is their main business here but I can’t say that the food here is super tasty.

Horrible. I walked through this so-called street food area and honestly, it was a disappointment. The noise was overwhelming, constant honking, loud scooters speeding by, and no sense of calm whatsoever. It didn’t feel cozy or inviting at all. I didn’t end up eating at any of the restaurants because the whole atmosphere put me off.

With all the traffic fumes and chaos, I can’t imagine it’s very healthy to sit and eat there. Definitely not the kind of street food experience I was hoping for.

Just happens to see this place on YouTube. We were there and   We ate the best escargot. It was crowded with motorbikes and pedestrians but we enjoyed our evening. We ate some grilled small birds and they were delicious 😋. We will come back again.
Thiên đường ẩm thực đường phố Việt Nam. The heaven of street food in Saigon where you can find any most famous stress food. Saigon hustle hard hustle harder for enjoying the way of life

Good place for seafood, but hawkers are a nuisance, they bother you as you eat.
If you don’t know Vietnamese and don’t know the right rejection gestures you are doomed

We were very underwhelmed with what we found. The seafood was expensive and food was not that good maybe we’re missing something but we wouldn’t come back we had some coffee and it was really good. At a corner cafe
The best street food we have found in HCMC. Many other street food streets we have visited have been devastated by COVID. They are dead or nearly so. A great range of food here, good atmosphere.

ops.insert: Memorial museum exhibiting photographs, weapons & other objects from the Vietnam & Indochina wars.
Sprawling underground tunnel complex used by Viet Cong soldiers, plus exhibits & war memorials.
Well-known standby for handicrafts, souvenirs, clothing & other goods along with local eats.
Monumental central post office, completed in 1891, with a vaulted main hall & period finishes.
Ornate 19th-century French colonial opera house that is now home to the city's ballet & symphony.

place.name: Ho Chi Minh City Museum of Fine Arts

ops.insert: Classical to contemporary Vietnamese & foreign artworks on display in an elegant colonial building.

place.name: Museum of Ho Chi Minh City

ops.insert: Historical building of the Vietnam War era, with tours of government offices, war rooms & artifacts.
1880s Catholic cathedral built with French bricks & featuring 58m-tall Romanesque bell towers.
Covered market with stalls selling home goods, produce & local dishes like pho & spring rolls.
Venerable Buddhist temple established in 1744, with many statues, tombs & a 7-tiered stupa.
Iconic 68-floor skyscraper featuring an observation deck, retail shops, dining & a cineplex.
Vietnamese artifacts & artworks from prehistoric to modern times in a large Chinese-style complex.
Catholic church dating to the 1870s & known for its vibrant pink facade & Gothic pillars.
Leafy public park featuring manicured gardens, a Buddhist temple, play areas & sports facilities.

place.name: The Golden Dragon Water Puppet Theater

ops.insert: Colorful venue for Vietnamese puppet shows performed in water & accompanied by live music.

place.name: Ho Chi Minh City People's Committee

ops.insert: French colonial city hall built in the early 1900s, now the headquarters of the People's Committee.
Straightforward zoo showcasing an array of animals, including giraffes, camels, elephants & snakes.

Cholon is Vietnam's largest Chinatown, where sprawling Binh Tay Market offers everything from fresh produce and seafood to fabric and lacquerware. Eateries and street food stalls selling Chinese-style noodles, roast pork, and salted duck eggs pack narrow lanes along with traditional herb stores. The 18th-century Thien Hau Temple holds a yearly festival to celebrate the birth anniversary of Mazu, goddess of the sea.
Theme park featuring a range of rides & water-based activities amid iconic Buddhist imagery.
Sprawling family-friendly entertainment complex with rides, a water park, cinema & zoo.

place.name: Compass Offices - Bitexco Financial Tower - Serviced Office Ho Chi Minh City

ops.insert: Lively thoroughfare known for its dining, shopping & drinking spots, especially busy at night.
Popular with backpackers, this busy hub features souvenir shops, bars, cafes & guest houses.
Traditional Vietnamese medicine is the focus of this eclectic museum with a replica pharmacy.
Sprawling Buddhist temple with traditional architecture, a 25m-tall tower & a vegetarian restaurant.

place.name: Khu căn cứ Vàm Sát Đảo Khỉ

ops.insert: Scenic, swampy mangrove forest featuring wild crocodiles & clever monkeys, along with a cafe.

Buzzing Pham Ngu Lao is centered on backpacker hotspot Bùi Viện street, where homestyle Vietnamese eateries sit next to tiny shops offering souvenirs, clothing, and tattoos. A raucous nightlife scene includes sidewalk beer cafes and back-alley dive bars, plus cocktail spots and dance clubs. The leafy September 23rd Park has a playground and duck pond, while elegant Huyện Sĩ Church is known for its soaring tower.
Glass-enclosed observation deck on the 49th floor of the Bitexco Financial Tower with scenic views.

place.name: Ho Chi Minh City Book Street

ops.insert: Buzzy, pedestrian-only street with Vietnamese & expat bookstores, plus spots for al fresco coffee.

Set by the Saigon River, Bình Quới Tourist Village encompasses grassy lawns, tree-shaded walking paths, and indoor/outdoor fishing ponds. Land-based restaurants offer seating in open-air thatched cottages, while a huge floating restaurant has set menus and buffets. Bamboo bridges overlook giant lily pads and water wheels in tranquil lakes. Shows featuring traditional music and dance entertain visitors in the evening.
This tall, prominent Buddhist pagoda built in 1956 was raided by government forces in 1963.

place.name: Hội quán Ôn Lăng - Chùa quan âm

ops.insert: Pagoda devoted to the Buddhist bodhisattva Quan Âm, featuring courtyards, a garden & a pond.

headerTemplate.blurbTemplate: Many of us love traveling on the Wanderlog team, so naturally we’re always on the hunt to find the most popular spots anytime we travel somewhere new. With favorites like [examplePlaceNames] and more, get ready to experience the best places in [geoNameWithThe].
headerTemplate.topBlurb:
Ho Chi Minh City, a bustling metropolis in Vietnam, is a vibrant tapestry of history, culture, and modernity. From the moment you step onto its lively streets, the energy is palpable, with the aroma of street food wafting through the air and the sounds of motorbikes zipping by. This city is a treasure trove of experiences, where ancient temples stand alongside colonial architecture, and bustling markets offer a glimpse into local life. Whether you're exploring the poignant exhibits at the War Remnants Museum or savoring the flavors at Ben Thanh Market, there's something here for every traveler.

As you navigate through Ho Chi Minh City, you'll uncover a mix of iconic landmarks and hidden gems that tell the story of its rich past and dynamic present. Imagine wandering through the historic Cu Chi Tunnels, where you can gain insight into the resilience of Vietnamese soldiers, or enjoying a serene moment at the Giac Lam Buddhist Temple, one of the oldest in the city. With so much to see and do, the Wanderlog team is excited to share our passion for discovering the best attractions and experiences that Ho Chi Minh City has to offer. So, pack your bags and get ready to explore this captivating destination!
